questions.text: During ward rounds, you encounter a patient who has been admitted with esophageal carcinoma. What is the most likely presentation for this patient?

choices.text: Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids
Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

Explanation:

Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids, as the tumour obstructs and narrows the esophagus.

 

Carcinoma Esophagus

Types
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • Adenocarcinoma

Risk Factors
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Smoking, Alcohol, Hot beverages, N-nitroso foods,
  • Adenocarcinoma: Obesity, Gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett's esophagus

Clinical Features
  • Progressive dysphagia (initially for solids followed by liquids), Anorexia, Weight loss, Odynophagia, and Regurgitation.
  • Advanced symptoms: Hoarseness, Aspiration, Choking, etc.

Investigation
  • Endoscopy: Tumor visualisation, Biopsies, Chromoendoscopy, NBI
  • Barium contrast study: Tumor as ulcerated/stenotic lesion
  • Bronchoscopy: Check airway spread
  • Endoscopic & Percutaneous Ultrasonography:
    • EUS for staging tumour (T stage) and para esophageal nodes Percutaneous ultrasound of cervical nodes with FNA
  • CT scan: Distant node assessment
  • FDG-PET scan: Detects nodes/metastases, not for tumour staging

 

Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids (Option A) is more typical of conditions like achalasia cardia, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Chest pain (Option C) can occur in esophageal carcinoma; it is less common as an initial presentation compared to dysphagia.

  • Chest pain in esophageal cancer usually occurs in advanced stages or if there is tumour invasion into nearby structures.

 

Neck mass (Option D) can occur if the cancer metastasises to the lymph nodes in the neck (e.g., Virchow's node), but this is not the most common initial presentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with peptic ulcer disease presents with persistent abdominal pain despite treatment at multiple hospitals. He has ulcers in the jejunum and ileum. His gastric pH is <2, and after discontinuing PPIs, his gastrin levels are 10 times higher than normal. What is the likely lesion, and what are the boundaries of the triangle containing it?

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Insulinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma; triangle formed by only common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

Explanation:

  • This patient’s clinical presentation of persistent peptic ulcers, especially in the jejunal and ileal regions, combined with elevated gastrin levels (even after stopping PPIs) and a gastric pH <2, is highly suggestive of a gastrinoma.
  • Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete excess gastrin, commonly leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which causes multiple peptic ulcers due to high gastric acid production.
  • The gastrinoma triangle refers to a specific anatomical region in the pancreas where gastrinomas are most commonly located. (Pissaros triangle) this triangle is bordered by:
    • Junction between cystic duct and CBD (option D ruled out)
    • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum (D2-D3 junction)
    • Junction between the head and neck of the pancreas


 


Insulinoma; triangle formed (Option A):

  • Insulinomas are pancreatic tumours that secrete insulin, not gastrin.
  • They cause hypoglycemia rather than peptic ulcers, so this option doesn’t fit with the patient’s symptoms or diagnostic findings. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: An intern assists in laparoscopic surgery, and the resident explains the instruments and operating ports. The surgeon then asks, "What is the angle between the camera port and the working port called?"
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azimuth's angle

Explanation:

  • Azimuth's angle is the correct term for describing the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery.
  • The ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° for maximum productivity.

Angles of laparoscopy

Azimuth angle

It is the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery; the ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° to avoid clashing of the instruments.

Manipulation angle

It is the angle between two working ports, and the ideal angle for this is 60°.

Elevation angle

This term is more related to the vertical positioning of instruments or the camera in relation to the surgical field, not the angle between ports; the ideal angle for this is also 60°.

 

Crossing angle (Option C) is not a term specifically used to describe the angle between the camera port and the working port.

questions.text: What is the Truelove and Witts classification used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ﻿﻿﻿Acute severe ulcerative colitis

Explanation:

The Truelove and Witts classification is specifically used to assess the severity of ulcerative colitis (UC).

Truelove and Witts classification for Ulcerative Colitis

Severity

Stool Frequency

Systemic Symptoms and signs

Mild

<4 stools/day

No systemic signs of toxicity

Moderate

>4 stools/day

Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP

Severe

>6 stools/day

Fever, tachycardia, anaemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminemia, Elevated ESR, CRP

Fulminant

>10 stools/day

Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases


ARDS (Option B) is acute respiratory distress syndrome involving the lungs, and the Truelove and Witts classification is not used for this.

 

Acute encephalitis (Option C) is an inflammation of the brain, typically caused by infection, and the Truelove and Witts classification has no role here.

 

Acute pancreatitis (Option D) is an inflammation of the pancreas, and it is not evaluated using the Truelove and Witts classification.

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation:

 


	
		
			
			A. Familial adenomatous polyposis
			
			
			i. SMAD4
			
		
		
			
			B. Juvenile polyposis
			
			
			ii. STK11
			
		
		
			
			C. Tuberous sclerosis
			
			
			iii. APC gene
			
		
		
			
			D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
			
			
			iv. TSC1
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-iii, B-i, C-iv, D-ii

Explanation:

A. Familial adenomatous polyposis

iii. APC gene

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterised by numerous intestinal polyps, which, if left untreated, have a high risk of developing colorectal cancer

B. Juvenile polyposis

i. SMAD4

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder that commonly affects children under 5 years of age,
  • It is characterised by pedunculated polyps, usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • It is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.

C. Tuberous sclerosis

iv. TSC1

  • It is a neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin) genes.
  • Patients exhibit neurological symptoms like seizures, along with skin abnormalities.
  • The syndrome also includes hamartomatous polyps in the intestine.

D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

ii. STK11

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the STK11 gene.
  • It presents around 11 years of age and is characterised by
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of melena that contains gastric mucosa and acute intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following structure was found, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Meckel's diverticulum

 

Explanation:

The presence of melena (dark tarry stools) suggests gastrointestinal bleeding.

The gastric mucosa in the ectopic location is a hallmark of Meckel's diverticulum.

Intermittent pain in the right iliac region can occur due to inflammation or obstruction.

Surgical exploration revealing a diverticular structure is characteristic of Meckel’s diverticulum.

Meckel's Diverticulum

Feature

Details

Definition

Congenital true diverticulum of the small intestine, resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.

Rule of 2’s

2% population, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2 inches in length, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric, pancreatic), 2 years most common presentation, 2:1 male predominance.

Clinical Features

Painless bleeding (melena), intestinal obstruction, diverticulitis, volvulus, intussusception.

Diagnosis

Meckel’s scan (Tc-99m pertechnetate scan for ectopic gastric mucosa).

Treatment

Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic.

 

Appendicular lump (Option B): incorrect because it typically presents with localized right lower quadrant pain, fever, and a mass due to inflammation, not melena or ectopic gastric mucosa.

 

Carcinoid (Option C): incorrect because carcinoid tumors present with flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing due to serotonin secretion, not intermittent pain and melena.

 

Obstructed bowel loops (Option D): incorrect because bowel obstruction typically presents with vomiting, distension, and absolute constipation, rather than melena and intermittent pain.

questions.text: A patient with grade 4 hemorrhoids underwent surgery, identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Haemorrhoid band kit

 

Explanation:

  • Grade 4 hemorrhoids are permanently prolapsed and require surgical intervention.
  • Rubber band ligation (RBL) is commonly used for hemorrhoid treatment, especially for grade 2 and 3 hemorrhoids, but may be attempted for early grade 4 cases before surgery.
  • If the patient underwent surgery, the most likely instrument used would be a hemorrhoidectomy (stapler or excision-based) rather than a band kit. However, if ligation was performed prior to surgery, a haemorrhoid band kit could have been used.

Hemorrhoid Treatment Options

Grade of Hemorrhoids

Treatment Options

Grade 1 (No prolapse)

Lifestyle modification, fiber, sitz bath, topical agents

Grade 2 (Prolapse, spontaneous reduction)

Rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared coagulation

Grade 3 (Prolapse, manual reduction needed)

Rubber band ligation, surgical excision if persistent symptoms

Grade 4 (Irreducible prolapse)

Surgical options: Hemorrhoidectomy (excision or stapler), laser hemorrhoidoplasty

Haemorrhoid resection kit (Option A): incorrect because resection is not performed using a specific "kit"; rather, standard surgical instruments or a stapler are used.

Stapler kit (Option B): incorrect because stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH) is an option, but not typically described as a "band kit".

CO2 laser (Option D): incorrect because laser hemorrhoidoplasty is an alternative to excision but is not the standard method for grade 4 hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with sudden onset acute abdominal pain, constipation for 1 day, persistent hiccups, and occasional vomiting. An abdominal X-ray was performed. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Sigmoid Volvulus

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical Features Suggest Bowel Obstruction:
    • Acute abdominal pain and constipation are classic features.
    • Persistent hiccups suggest diaphragmatic irritation due to massive bowel distension.
    • Vomiting occurs as obstruction progresses.
  • X-ray Findings:
    • Massively dilated sigmoid colon with a characteristic "coffee bean" or "omega loop" sign.
    • Few or no air-fluid levels, differentiating it from a small bowel obstruction.
    • Absence of significant small bowel dilatation, favoring sigmoid over caecal volvulus.
  • Management:
    • Initial: Sigmoidoscopic detorsion.
    • Definitive: Elective sigmoidectomy to prevent recurrence.
    • Emergency: If gangrene or perforation is suspected, immediate surgery is required.

Volvulus Types & Features

Feature

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus

Cause

Twisting of sigmoid colon on its mesentery

Twisting of caecum & ascending colon

X-ray Sign

"Coffee bean" or "Omega loop" sign

"Comma" or "Kidney bean" sign

Bowel Dilatation

Sigmoid colon massively distended

Dilated caecum, displaced medially

Management

Endoscopic detorsion or surgery

Surgery (right hemicolectomy if gangrenous)

Caecal Volvulus (Option B): incorrect because caecal volvulus typically shows a comma-shaped distended caecum in the right abdomen, unlike the coffee bean sign of sigmoid volvulus.

Intussusception (Option C): incorrect because intussusception presents with a target sign on ultrasound, rather than massive colonic dilation on X-ray.

Dynamic Obstruction (Option D): incorrect because sigmoid volvulus is a mechanical obstruction rather than a functional or paralytic one.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male undergoes an open appendectomy for acute appendicitis. The choice of incision was McBurney's incision. Postoperatively, after a few days, he presents with pain and bulging in the right lower quadrant, which is diagnosed as an indirect inguinal hernia. Which nerve injury during the appendectomy is most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ilioinguinal nerve

Explanation:

  • Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve during an appendectomy, especially with McBurney's incision, is a documented complication that can lead to weakness of the inguinal canal structures.

  • This weakness can predispose the patient to the development of an indirect inguinal hernia.

The complications associated with appendectomy are listed below:

Complication

Description

1. Wound infection

The MC postoperative complication involves infection at the surgical site.

2. Intraabdominal abscess

Collection of pus within the abdominal cavity, typically due to infection.

3. Ileus

Temporary cessation of bowel function, leading to abdominal distension and discomfort.

4. Venous thrombosis leading to embolism

Formation of blood clots in the veins, which can travel to the lungs or other parts of the body.

5. Portal pyaemia (Pylephlebitis)

Infection and thrombosis of the portal vein, a rare but serious complication.

6. Adhesive intestinal obstruction

Formation of scar tissue causing bowel obstruction; MC late complication

7. Fecal fistula

Leakage from the appendiceal stump.

8. Nerve injury

Injury to the Ilioinguinal nerve and iliohypogastric nerve

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of lower right abdominal pain and rebound tenderness in a patient with Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Appendicitis

 

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate acute appendicitis, despite the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Lower right abdominal pain with rebound tenderness is a classic sign of acute appendicitis, and the presence of a Meckel's diverticulum does not change this presentation. While Meckel's diverticulum can cause abdominal pain, the specific location and presence of rebound tenderness strongly suggest appendicitis as the primary pathology.

 

Perforation (Option A): While perforation of Meckel's diverticulum can occur, it typically presents with more diffuse abdominal pain and peritonitis rather than localized right lower quadrant pain. The presentation described is more consistent with appendicitis (Option A ruled out). Perforation would likely cause more widespread symptoms and signs of peritoneal irritation.

 

Intestinal obstruction (Option B): Meckel's diverticulum can cause intestinal obstruction, but this typically presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention rather than localized rebound tenderness (Option B ruled out). The absence of these obstruction symptoms makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Cholecystitis (Option D): Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, not lower right abdominal pain. The location of pain and the presence of rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant is inconsistent with cholecystitis (Option D ruled out). Murphy's sign would be expected in cholecystitis, which is elicited in the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: Endoscopic image show following finding what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Esophageal varices:

  • Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the esophagus, typically seen in patients with portal hypertension, often due to liver cirrhosis. Endoscopically, they appear as prominent, tortuous veins along the esophageal wall, which is the key feature in the described image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Barrett’s esophagus: Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by the replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Endoscopically, it appears as salmon-colored mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. It does not present with dilated veins.

Option C - Gastric erosion: Gastric erosions are superficial mucosal defects in the stomach lining. They may appear as small, shallow ulcers or red, inflamed areas during endoscopy, usually in the gastric mucosa, not the esophagus.

Option D - Chronic GERD: Chronic GERD leads to mucosal changes in the esophagus, such as erosive esophagitis, strictures, or Barrett’s esophagus. However, it does not cause the appearance of dilated veins seen with esophageal varices.

questions.text: A patient presents with an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Correct A - Umbilical excision:

  • Given the change in the hernia's characteristics from reducible to irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision is the most appropriate treatment to address the potential complications associated with the irreducible mass. surgical intervention should focus on excising the strangulated tissue and do  suture repair.  Then plan for a definite repair after few days. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Umbilical excision with mesh hernioplasty:

  • This option combines the excision of the umbilicus with the reinforcement of the abdominal wall using a mesh to prevent recurrence. It is often used in larger hernias or when there is significant weakening of the abdominal wall. Mesh hernioplasty is contraindicated in stangulation

Option C - Mesh hernioplasty:

  • This involves reinforcing the abdominal wall defect with a mesh without excising the umbilicus. It is generally used for larger or recurrent hernias to prevent recurrence. However, in the case of an irreducible hernia with concern about the umbilical skin viability, mesh hernioplasty is contraindicated in stangulation

Option D - Conservative management:

  • Conservative management is generally not appropriate for an irreducible hernia, as there is a risk of complications such as strangulation or bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A jeep driver presented with pain in the gluteal region along with swelling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pilonidal sinus:

  • A pilonidal sinus is a small, tunnel-like lesion that typically occurs near the sacrococcygeal area (lower back near the tailbone). It is often caused by an ingrown hair or debris that becomes trapped, leading to inflammation and infection.
  • Pain, swelling, and sometimes discharge or abscess formation in the gluteal region. The condition is more common in people who sit for prolonged periods, such as jeep drivers.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fistula in ano:

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the skin around the anus. It usually results from an infection or abscess in the anal region.
  • Pain, swelling, and discharge around the anus, rather than the gluteal region. The pain and swelling are typically localized around the anus and not in the gluteal area.

Option C - Fissure in ano:

  • An anal fissure is a small tear in the lining of the anus, often caused by trauma or strain during bowel movements.
  • Severe pain during and after bowel movements, possibly with bleeding, but usually localized to the anal region rather than the gluteal region.

Option D - Gluteal abscess:

  • A gluteal abscess is a collection of pus in the gluteal region, often due to infection. It may be related to trauma or infection.
  • Pain, swelling, and redness in the gluteal region. While this condition could fit the description, pilonidal sinus is more specific to the scenario described, especially in the context of prolonged sitting.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with recurrent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy following finding. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pseudomembranous colitis:

  • This condition is characterized by inflammation of the colon due to an overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile, often after antibiotic use. The hallmark of this disease on colonoscopy is the presence of raised, yellowish-white plaques or pseudomembranes on the mucosa, which can be seen as the yellowish findings described. Symptoms include recurrent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP): FAP is an inherited disorder characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. Patients typically do not present with recurrent diarrhea or foul-smelling stools but are at high risk for colorectal cancer. The colonoscopy findings in FAP would show numerous polyps rather than pseudomembranes.

Option C - Ulcerative colitis: This is an inflammatory bowel disease that causes chronic inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa. While patients may present with abdominal pain and diarrhea, the colonoscopy findings usually show continuous inflammation and ulceration, not pseudomembranes.

Option D - Acute gastritis: This condition involves inflammation of the stomach lining and typically presents with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting rather than diarrhea. Colonoscopy is not used to diagnose gastritis as it affects the stomach, not the colon.

questions.text: Identify the procedure commonly performed in patients with recurrent gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 360-degree Nissen fundoplication:

  • It is the most common surgical procedure performed for recurrent GERD. In this procedure, the fundus of the stomach is wrapped completely (360 degrees) around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, preventing acid reflux.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Partial gastrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of a portion of the stomach. It is not typically used for GERD treatment but rather for conditions like stomach cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease.

Option C - Esophageal banding: This procedure involves placing a band around the esophagus, typically used to treat esophageal varices in patients with portal hypertension, not for GERD.

Option D - 270-degree Nissen fundoplication: Also known as Toupet fundoplication, this procedure involves a partial (270 degrees) wrap of the stomach around the esophagus. While it can be used to treat GERD, it is less common than the 360-degree Nissen fundoplication, particularly in cases of recurrent GERD.

questions.text: A child with recurrent vomiting undergoes an x-ray, as shown below. What is the most likely electrolyte imbalance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypokalemia

Explanation:

The "single bubble" sign on an X-ray is a characteristic feature of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS), which is commonly associated with hypokalemia resulting from the loss of potassium due to persistent vomiting.

Congenital (Infantile) Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (HPS): Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pyloric antral musculature, particularly the circular muscle fibers, leading to the failure of the pylorus to relax. The duodenum remains normal.

  • Increased risk if the newborn is administered erythromycin or azithromycin within the first 14 days of life.
  • Symptoms typically develop between the 3rd and 6th week of life, as hypertrophy of the muscle leads to complete obstruction.

  • Vomiting: Forcible, projectile, and non-bilious.
  • Visible Gastric Peristalsis (VGP)
  • Palpable Olive-like Mass: A smooth, mobile, firm, olive-shaped mass is felt on the left side of the abdomen. It moves with respiration, has well-defined borders, and demonstrates impaired resonance on percussion. This is the most important clinical feature (95% of cases).
  • Constipation, dehydration & Weight Loss
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Examination: Primary method for diagnosis.
    • Ultrasound Abdomen: Highly useful for diagnosis, showing
      • Doughnut Sign.
      • Pyloric Muscle Thickness: 4 mm or more.
      • Pyloric Canal Length: > 14 mm.
      • Cervix Sign (long axis) & Target Sign (short axis).
    • Barium Meal: May show obstruction, but it is less commonly used. When done, it may demonstrate.
      • String Sign, Railroad Track Sign, or Double Track Sign due to pyloric obstruction.
  • Treatment:
    • Correct Dehydration & Electrolyte Imbalance.
    • Surgery:
      • Ramstedt's Operation: Pyloromyotomy via laparotomy, ensuring mucosa is not breached.
      • Laparoscopic Pyloromyotomy.
      • Endoscopic Pyloromyotomy.
      • Balloon Dilation (less effective).

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly injured during indirect inguinal hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ilioinguinal nerve

Explanation:

The most commonly injured nerve during open inguinal hernia surgery is the ilioinguinal nerve, often leading to chronic pain as a complication.

  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve.
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterization.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for pilonidal sinus, which type of flap is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rhomboid flap

Explanation:

The Rhomboid flap is often used in pilonidal sinus surgery, especially when excision of the sinus results in a defect that requires tissue advancement to close. This flap allows for tension-free closure and ensures the area is adequately covered, helping to prevent recurrence of the sinus.

Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair.

  • Acquired Condition: Pilonidal sinuses are now considered acquired rather than congenital.
  • Causes:
    • Friction and shearing forces between the skin folds can cause loose hairs to penetrate the skin.
    • Movement of the skin folds may create suction, pulling hair into the skin and forming a chronically infected track, which can develop secondary tracks with discharging openings.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Demographics: More common in men, typically presenting after puberty and before age 40, prevalent in individuals with dark, coarse hair.
  • Symptoms:
    • Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
    • History of recurring abscesses, which may burst spontaneously or require incision.

Treatment Options:

Treatment Type

Description

Conservative Treatment
  • For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
  • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases.

Acute Abscess Treatment
  • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess.
  • Thorough cleaning of the abscess cavity to remove granulation tissue and hair.

Surgical Treatment

Procedures include:

  • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
  • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
  • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
  • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
  • Flap Procedures: Used if initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs.

Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap:

  • Off-midline closures are associated with lower recurrence rates and faster healing than midline closures.

questions.text: Which incision is most commonly used for an appendectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) McBurney incision

Explanation:

McBurney incision is the classic and most commonly used incision for an appendectomy. It is located in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, where the appendix is typically found.

Incision Type

Description

Common Uses

Abdominal Incisions

Midline

Longitudinal cut through the linea alba, bloodless access

Exploratory laparotomy, trauma surgery, emergency surgeries

Periumbilical

Incisions around the umbilicus, avoiding the umbilical stalk

Laparoscopy, umbilical hernia repairs, postpartum tubal ligation

Pararectus

Along the semilunar line, lateral to the rectus abdominis

Abdominal wall hernia repairs, stoma creation, pelvic surgeries

Paramedian

Lateral to the linea alba, access to lateral viscera

Lateral abdominal structures,

Reduced hernia risk

Kocher/Subcostal

Inferior and parallel to the costal margin, access to upper abdomen structures

Gallbladder, biliary tree, pancreas, liver transplants, epigastric surgeries

Grindiron/

McBurney/

Lanz

Lower abdomen incisions, typically for appendectomy

Appendectomy (right side), sigmoid diverticulitis (left side), cosmetic appendectomy

Thoracoabdominal

From 7th intercostal space to the umbilicus, exposes thoracic and abdominal organs

Retroperitoneal masses, pleural space, distal esophagus, abdominal organs

Thoracic Incisions

Thoracotomy

Access to thoracic structures, various approaches

Lung transplants, cardiac surgeries, trauma

Median Sternotomy

Vertical incision dividing the sternum, wide access to the mediastinum

Open-heart surgery, anterior mediastinal tumor resection

Trapdoor

Complex incision, supraclavicular, sternal, and thoracotomy components

Penetrating trauma, aortic arch aneurysms, complex cardiovascular access

Infraclavicular

A transverse incision just below the clavicle for subclavian vessel access

Thoracic outlet syndrome, subclavian vessel surgeries

Supraclavicular

Superior to the clavicle, providing access to the subclavian vessels

Trauma, thoracic outlet syndrome

Neck Incisions

Collar

Incision above the sternal notch for thyroid surgeries

Thyroid surgery, mid-neck structures

Traumatic Neck

Along the sternocleidomastoid muscle for trauma

Vascular or traumatic neck injuries

Tracheostomy

Vertical/horizontal incision superior to the thyroid for tracheostomy

Airway management in patients needing long-term ventilation

Pelvic Incisions

Pfannenstiel

Transverse incision above the pubic symphysis

Cesarean section, pelvic, urologic, and orthopaedic surgeries

Maylard/Cherney

Above pubic tubercle, provides access to pelvic structures

Hysterectomy, pelvic lymph node dissection, lower pelvis surgeries

Inguinal

Above and parallel to the inguinal ligament

Inguinal hernia repair, urologic surgeries (cryptorchidism, varicocele)

McEvedy

Vertical incision for femoral hernia repair

Femoral hernia repair (obsolete now due to high hernia recurrence rate)

Gibson

Above inguinal ligament, arc to the lateral rectus sheath

Kidney transplantation, retroperitoneal access (iliac vessels, ureter)

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumoperitoneum is noted on X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophageal perforation

Explanation:

  • Esophageal perforation, particularly Boerhaave’s syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis. The patient’s history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals, combined with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, strongly suggests a rupture of the esophagus. (Boerhaave’s syndrome)
  • Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by spontaneous esophageal perforation due to forceful vomiting. Key features include severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema.

Esophageal perforation

Definition

A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality

Causes

Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer

Symptoms
  • Varies by cause and location:
  • Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation)
  • Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema)
  • Cervical (neck pain, etc.)

Diagnosis

Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan

Management
  • Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control)
  • Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation
  • Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement
  • Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation
  • Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare)

Incorrect Options:

Mediastinal air leak (Option A) can be a result of various causes, including trauma or infections, but the patient’s history and symptoms make esophageal perforation more likely.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option C) refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, often due to a perforated abdominal viscus, such as a perforated ulcer. However, the patient's presentation are more consistent with esophageal perforation.

Peptic ulcer (Option D) can cause abdominal pain and potentially lead to perforation, but it typically does not cause chest pain radiating to the shoulder or the presence of pneumoperitoneum as seen in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bone marrow failure

Explanation: Bone marrow failure (Option D) is not typically an indication for splenectomy. Bone marrow failure syndromes like aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other causes of bone marrow suppression usually require treatment to support bone marrow function (e.g., transfusions, medications, or stem cell transplantation), rather than removal of the spleen

Indications for Splenecomy:

  • Hodgkin Lymphoma & Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Hairy Cell Leukemia (Option C)
  • CLL & CML
  • Splenic Marginal Zone Lymphoma
  • Metastatic Splenic Tumors
  • Splenic Cysts (True and Pseudocysts)
  • Splenic Abscess
  • Angiosarcoma (Hemangiosarcoma)
  • Lymphangioma and Lymphangiosarcoma
  • Traumatic Splenic Rupture (Option A)
  • Hypersplenism (due to various hematologic conditions)
  • Non-Hematologic Primary Tumors (e.g., splenic hemangiomas)
  • Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP) (Option B)
  • Hereditary Spherocytosis & Elliptocytosis
  • Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD)
  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase Deficiency (G6PD)
  • Sickle Cell Disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Acute Splenic Sequestration Crisis (in sickle cell disease or sickle-beta thalassemia)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a left groin swelling for a few years, which increases in size on standing and decreases when lying down. On examination, the swelling shows a positive cough impulse. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Reduction of contents, repair defects and reinforcement with mesh

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reduction of contents, repair defect and reinforcement with mesh

Explanation:

The patient's presentation with a groin swelling that increases in size on standing, decreases when lying down, and shows a positive cough impulse is indicative of an inguinal hernia. Thus, the most appropriate management for this patient is reduction of contents, repair of the defect, and reinforcement with mesh.

Management of Inguinal Hernia:

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy: (Option B)
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates.
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh.
  • Herniorrhaphy: (Option C)
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures
    • Techniques:

Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates.

 

Shouldice Repair involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

 

 

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair: Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery.

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair: (Option D)
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair

 

TEP

TAPP

Procedure

Surgery done above the peritoneum

Surgery done beneath the peritoneum

Advantages
  • Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications.
  • Reduced risk of adhesions.
  • Larger working space
  • Better visualisation

Disadvantages

Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging.
  • A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

Incision and drainage (Option A) are typically used in cases of abscess or infection, which isn't the case here since the swelling is consistent with a hernia, not an infection.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach's triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vas deferens

Explanation:

  • The vas deferens do not form a boundary of Hesselbach's triangle. It passes through the inguinal canal and is located posterior to the inguinal ligament, but it is not part of the triangle's boundaries.

Hesselbach’s Triangle:

  • A weak spot in the abdominal wall, where direct inguinal hernias occur.
  • Covered only by the transversalis fascia and external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Susceptible to herniation, especially in elderly patients or those with increased abdominal pressure.
  • Boundaries:
    • Lateral border: Inferior epigastric vessels (Option A)
    • Medial border: Rectus abdominis muscle (Option C)
    • Inferior border: Inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament) (Option D)

​​​​​​​

questions.text: What is the type of hernia in which the internal organ forms a portion of the wall of the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia

Explanation:

  • A sliding hernia occurs when a part of an internal organ, such as the colon or bladder, forms part of the wall of the hernia sac.

Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade):

  • It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ.
  • More common in males, particularly the elderly (Option A ruled out) and frequently occurs on the left side, where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix. (Option D ruled out)
  • The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall. (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement.
  • Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect, but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac.

 

Incorrect Options:

Lumbar hernia (Option A) refers to hernias occurring in the lumbar region of the abdominal wall but does not involve an internal organ forming part of the wall of the sac.

Spigelian hernia (Option C) occurs through the Spigelian fascia, which is located on the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle and does not involve an internal organ as part of the hernia sac wall.

Richter hernia (Option D) is a type of hernia in which only a portion of the bowel wall (usually the antimesenteric border) is incarcerated, but it does not form the wall of the hernia sac.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of epigastric pain for 1 day. On examination, his heart rate is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. There is tenderness, guarding, and rigidity on palpation. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, what is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings that show free air under the diaphragm, which is a classic sign of perforation, suggest hollow viscus perforation.

A hollow viscus perforation occurs when there is a rupture or hole in a hollow organ (such as the stomach, small intestine, large intestine, or duodenum), allowing its contents to spill into the peritoneal cavity. This leads to peritonitis, a potentially life-threatening condition.

  • Clinical features:
    • Acute onset of severe abdominal pain, often described as sharp or stabbing.
    • Generalized peritonitis:
      • Tenderness and guarding over the entire abdomen.
      • Rigidity (board-like abdomen).
    • Tachycardia is due to pain and a systemic response to infection.
    • Hypotension due to septic shock or fluid loss into the peritoneum.
    • Nausea and vomiting are common & fever may develop as a sign of infection.
  • Causes:
    • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common cause, especially in duodenum).
    • Trauma (e.g., stab or gunshot wounds).
    • Diverticulitis leads to colonic perforation.
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn’s disease).
    • Appendicitis that progresses to rupture.
    • Foreign body ingestion leads to injury or perforation.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Free air under the diaphragm (classic sign) indicates that air has escaped into the peritoneal cavity.
    • It may show air-fluid levels if associated with bowel obstruction.
  • CECT: Most sensitive to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management:
    • Surgical intervention: Exploratory laparotomy done after stabilisation.
    • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are started to treat peritonitis and prevent septic shock.
    • Fluid resuscitation: IV fluids are crucial to support blood pressure and organ function, especially in cases of sepsis.

Incorrect Options:

Acute cholecystitis (Option A) typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and a positive Murphy's sign, but it is less likely to present with generalised peritonitis (rigidity, guarding) or hypotension.

Sigmoid volvulus (Option C) typically presents with abdominal distension and onstipation, may show a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray.

Small bowel obstruction (Option D) can present with pain, distension, and vomiting, but the key finding in small bowel obstruction is dilated loops of bowel on X-ray, not free air (unless there is a perforation, which is less common). In cases of jejunal obstruction, valvulae conniventes, which are mucosal folds that span the entire diameter of the bowel, create a ladder effect.

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, while inserting the trocar, which of the following is most prone to injury?

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries

Explanation:

  • Both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries are at the highest risk during trocar placement due to their superficial and relatively consistent anatomical location in the anterior abdominal wall.
  • The superior and inferior epigastric arteries run vertically within the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle. This creates a high-risk zone for injury during trocar insertion, especially in the lower abdomen.
  • The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic artery, while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery. These arteries anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and superficial course within the anterior abdominal wall make them particularly vulnerable to injury when a trocar is placed incorrectly.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray shows air under the diaphragm. The patient is taken up for surgery, and an ileal perforation is noted intraoperatively with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy

Explanation:

  • Given the gross contamination with enteric and purulent contents, faecal diversion via ileostomy is usually recommended. This helps to prevent further contamination and allows the infected peritoneum to heal while diverting the faecal contents away from the abdomen.

Types of Stomas:

Type

Description

Common Uses

Reversibility

End Colostomy

Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent.

Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure

Often permanent

Loop Ileostomy

Loop of the bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made

Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible

Usually temporary

Double-barrel Colostomy

Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge

Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula

Can be temporary

Permanent Ileostomy

Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy

Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP

Permanent

Incorrect Options:

Resection and anastomosis (Option A) is typically used in cases of multiple perforations, malignancy, suspected gangrene, or if there is significant tissue loss. It is not recommended in cases with severe peritoneal contamination, as the risk of infection, abscess formation, and anastomotic leak is high.

Primary repair (Option B) is typically reserved for small perforations with minimal contamination and no signs of peritonitis.

Omental patch closure (Option D): While duodenal perforations are often treated with an omentum patch without resection, ileal perforations with significant contamination generally require more aggressive management, such as an ileostomy, to prevent sepsis and further complications.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the abdomen for 1.5 years. She has a history of midline surgery. On examination, the swelling is 4 cm and is reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planning to undergo fascial closure with mesh repair. What is the most likely location of the mesh shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Onlay

Explanation:

  • This patient most likely has an incisional hernia, which is a common complication following midline surgery, characterised by a bulge or swelling at the site of a previous incision.
  • The treatment often involves fascial closure with mesh repair to reinforce the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The given image shows Onlay mesh repair technique.

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from the posterior rectus sheath; mesh is placed in this space, and the peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common hernia in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Indirect inguinal hernia:

  • Indirect inguinal hernia is the most common hernia among both males and females with an incidence of 53.6% and 32.9% respectively.
  • In Indirect inguinal hernia, the sac enters the deep ring and comes out through the superficial ring.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Direct Inguinal hernia: Direct Inguinal hernia is the second most common hernia in males but its incidence is only 1.5% in females.

Option C - Femoral hernia: Femoral hernia is more common in females than males and has an incidence of 11.1%.

Option D - Obturator hernia: Obturator hernia is a rare type of hernia occurring due to loss of fatty tissue in the obturator canal leading to laxity of the ligaments.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the clinic with complaints of food regurgitation and weight loss over the past several months. A barium swallow test is performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achalasia cardia:

  • The above image is a barium swallow showing Rat tail appearance which is a diagnostic feature of Achalasia cardia.
  • Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.
  • It presents with clincal triad of dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss.
  • On barium swallow it shows Bird’s beak appearance/pencil tip appearance/Rat tail appearance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal carcinoma presents with progressive dysphagia nad on barium swallow it shows apple core appearance.

Option C - Zenker's diverticulum: Zenker's diverticulum presents with dysphagia, aspiration pneumonitis, cervical web, halitosis. But weight loss is not a feature of Zenker's diverticulum.

Option D - Diffuse esophageal spasm: Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with chest pain, dysphagia and on barium swallow it shows corkscrew or rosary bead appearance.

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma?


	Hepatitis B
	PSC
	Caroli's disease
	Opisthorchis viverrini
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, 3, and 4:

  • All of the above are the risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options.

questions.text: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. USG shows distention of the portal vein and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been initiated. What is the next appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement:

  • The above clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of upper GI bleed.
  • The management of upper GI bleeding includes
    • PPI/Tranexamic acid/Octreotide administration.
    • IV fluids and electrolyte replacement to stabilize the patient.
    • Following this endoscopic variceal ligation is performed followed by endoscopic sclerotherapy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are initiated only after the bleeding has been controlled.

Option B - Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis: Liver biopsy is not necessary in the initial management of upper GI bleed.

Option D - Perform an endoscopy to look for varices: Endoscopy is performed after administration of pharmacotherapy and IV fluids.

questions.text: Identify the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PEG tube:

  • The above given image is of the Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy set.
  • The most common indications for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) include impaired swallowing mechanisms, oropharyngeal or esophageal obstruction, and major facial trauma.
  • It is frequently used for debilitated patients requiring caloric supplementation, hydration, or frequent medication dosing.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central line: Central line is used for volume resuscitation, CVP monitoring.

Option C - Orogastric tube insertion: Orogastric tube is used in suctioning of gastric contents, decompression, prevention of aspiration.

Option D - ICD: ICD is used in case of massive hemothorax, tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appeared cyanotic, with increased breathing work. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. A chest x-ray is given in the image. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Explanation:

The history provided, along with the chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels above the diaphragm, strongly suggests a diagnosis of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia: CDH is a birth defect with an abnormal opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and severely impair lung development.

  • Most Common Side: Left (84%) > Right
  • It is of two types:
    • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of CDH due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.
    • Morgagni Hernia is due to the defective Central tendon.

 

Difference between Bochdalek and Morgagni Hernia:

Feature

Bochdalek Hernia

Morgagni Hernia

Side

Left-sided

Right-sided

Location

Posterolateral

Anteromedial

Herniated Organs

Small intestine, stomach

Transverse colon, sometimes liver

Common Symptoms

Scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, mediastinal shift

Mostly Asymptomatic and Incidental

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Less severe respiratory distress

Association

Polyhydramnios, abnormal LHR, and liver position

Rarely detected prenatally; usually diagnosed later

Management

Variable

Generally Better prognosis

 Incorrect Options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B) The chest X-ray in Tetralogy of Fallot typically shows a boot-shaped heart.

Transposition of the great vessels (Option C) The chest X-ray for transposition of the great vessels shows an "egg-on-a-string" appearance of the heart.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option D) In tracheoesophageal fistula, a chest X-ray will often show a coiled nasogastric tube in the upper esophageal pouch.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamocolumnar junction located more proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia

 

Explanation:

Sliding hernia is the most likely cause of the squamocolumnar junction being located more proximally than normal. This condition involves the upward displacement of the gastroesophageal junction into the thorax, which can result in the squamocolumnar junction appearing higher during an endoscopic examination.

 

Hiatus Hernia: Condition in which the abdominal contents pass through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum.

 

Types

Description

Type I/Sliding Hiatus Hernia

The most common type.

The gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up through the diaphragm.

Type II/Paraesophageal Hiatus Hernia

Part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm next to the oesophagus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in place.

Type III/Mixed Hiatus Hernia

Combines features of both sliding and paraesophageal hernias.

Type IV

Involves viscera other than the stomach in the hernial sac, like the colon.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Achalasia cardia (Option A) typically causes failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a dilated esophagus and difficulties with swallowing, but it doesn't affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction.

Rolling hernia (Option C) (also called paraesophageal hernias) involves part of the stomach rolling into the chest beside the esophagus, but this does not typically affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (Option D) is associated with acid reflux and damage to the esophagus but does not cause the squamocolumnar junction to move proximally.

Clinical Features: Heartburn, regurgitation of food, chest pain.

Diagnosis: Barium swallow X-Ray, Esophageal manometry.

Treatment: PPI, Nissen Fundoplication, Hernia repair.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucinous cystadenoma

Explanation:

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, often caused by a rupture of a mucin-producing tumor like Mucinous cystadenoma.

Pseudomyxoma Peritonei (PMP) is a rare, life-threatening condition characterized by progressive peritoneal tumour deposits, mucinous ascites, omental cake, and ovarian involvement. It is most commonly caused by the rupture of a mucinous appendiceal tumour. Symptoms include abdominal distension, anorexia, and bowel dysfunction.

  • Classification: PMP is graded based on cytological atypia in peritoneal deposits:
    • Acellular mucin
    • Low-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei
    • High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei
    • High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei with signet ring cells

Treatment: The standard approach is Cytoreductive Surgery (CRS) combined with Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC). This extensive surgery, including organ removals, aims for complete tumour clearance. Survival rates after complete cytoreduction are 87% at 5 years and 70% at 10 years.

Chemotherapy may be used for high-grade, unresectable cases or post-surgery in high-risk patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice in a pregnant woman with an anal wart, as shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen

Explanation:

The image suggests a diagnosis of condyloma acuminata, which is the most common sexually transmitted anal disease caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is the treatment of choice for removing anal warts in pregnant women.

  • The advantage of cryotherapy is that it is relatively bloodless, painless, and allows precise control over the depth and extent of freezing.

Condylomata Acuminata (Genital Warts): Genital warts are caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) and are transmitted sexually. HPV infection is common, but only a small proportion of infected individuals develop visible warts. HPV types 6 and 11 are the most common causes of genital warts, and these types are not linked to cervical cancer.

  • Genital warts are distinct from ordinary skin warts, as they tend to be softer, moister, and more often pedunculated.
  • In women, warts are typically seen on the vulva and may line the vagina or appear on the cervix. Perianal warts are also common.
  • Treatment Options:
    • Podophyllin is a commonly used topical treatment. It is applied directly to the wart and carefully washed off after about 6 hours.
    • An alternative chemical treatment is imiquimod.
    • If chemical treatments are ineffective, other methods include cryosurgery, electrosurgery, laser ablation, or surgical excision.
    • Circumcision may be recommended in cases of extensive lesions under the foreskin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient who underwent gastrointestinal surgery one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible 12 cm incisional hernia. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use
Advise observation and reassessment in six months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair

 

 

Explanation:

The gold standard treatment for an incisional hernia is intra-peritoneal onlay mesh repair.

  • Mesh repair is preferred because it significantly reduces the risk of recurrence compared to other methods.
  • An incisional hernia, also known as a post-operative ventral wall hernia, occurs when fascial tissues fail to fuse properly after surgery.

 

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

Incorrect Options:

Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use (Option B): An abdominal belt may be prescribed temporarily for support and improved wound healing post-surgery, but it does not treat the hernia itself.

Advise observation and reassessment in six months (Option C): This approach is not recommended, as incisional hernias can lead to complications such as strangulation, obstruction, and incarceration if left untreated.

Laparoscopic closure without mesh (Option D) is not advisable due to higher recurrence rates associated with this approach. Mesh repair offers a more reliable long-term solution.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical wall repair

Explanation:

  • Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the baby is born with the intestines exposed through a hole in the abdominal wall. The most appropriate treatment is surgical wall repair, where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdomen, and the defect is closed.

Feature

Omphalocele

Gastroschisis

Definition

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus.

Congenital abdominal wall defect is when abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus.

Covering

The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner).

No membrane covers the exposed organs.

Associated conditions
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21.
  • Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU")
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma.
  • Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele.
  • Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction.

Prognosis

Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death.

Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies.

Management
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
  • Larger defects may require:
  • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
  • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
  • Skin flap closure, or
  • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
  • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • Primary closure is typically done under general anesthesia and often requires admission to the NICU for postoperative ventilation.
  • Alternatively, a preformed silo can be placed at the bedside for gradual reduction, sometimes avoiding the need for general anesthesia altogether.

 

Incorrect Options:

Wait and watch (Option B): This approach is not recommended as it can lead to complications such as fluid loss, hypothermia, hypovolemia, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, and necrotizing enterocolitis.

Slowly putting it inside (Option C): While the intestines are gradually pushed back inside during primary closure, this is not a management option by itself.

Surgical excision (Option D) is only performed for non-viable bowel followed by anastomosis.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Omphalocele

Explanation:

The given image shows Omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a central abdominal wall defect typically larger than 4 cm in diameter, characterized by an intact membranous sac composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum. Defects smaller than 4 cm are classified as umbilical cord hernias.

  • Associated anomalies:
    • 50% of infants with omphalocele have associated anomalies, including:
      • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: A combination of gigantism, macroglossia, and an umbilical defect (either hernia or omphalocele).
      • Chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies 13, 15, 18, and 21.
      • Other conditions like bladder exstrophy, cloaca, and pentalogy of Cantrell, which includes:
        • Omphalocele
        • Anterior diaphragmatic hernia
        • Sternal cleft
        • Ectopia cordis
        • Intracardiac defects, like ventricular septal defect.
  • Initial management:
    • The presence of an intact omphalocele sac is crucial for initial management.
    • Preventing hypothermia is a primary concern.
    • A comprehensive diagnostic workup is performed to identify associated anomalies.
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
    • Larger defects may require:
      • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
      • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
      • Skin flap closure, or
      • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
    • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • The overall survival of infants with omphalocele depends largely on their lung maturity and the severity of associated anomalies.

 

Urachal cyst (Option B) is a fluid-filled sac that results from the incomplete closure of the urachus (a remnant of the connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord). It doesn't present as an abdominal wall defect like omphalocele.

Umbilical hernia (Option C) occurs when part of the intestine or other abdominal contents protrude through the umbilical opening in the abdominal muscles. It’s usually smaller and has no sac covering the contents, as seen in omphalocele.

Umbilical adenoma (Option D) is a benign tumour located in or near the umbilicus, unrelated to abdominal wall defects like omphalocele.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hollow viscus

 

Explanation: Hollow viscus (such as the small and large intestines) is the most commonly affected organ in seat belt injuries.

 

Seat belt injury:

  • The mesentery, a fold of tissue that attaches the intestines to the posterior abdominal wall, is particularly vulnerable in seat belt injuries due to the compressive force of the belt across the abdomen.
  • This can lead to mesenteric tears, avulsions, or hematomas, resulting in internal bleeding or ischemia, which often require surgical intervention to prevent complications like bowel necrosis.
  • The classical seat belt sign refers to a distinctive pattern of bruising or contusion across the abdomen and chest resulting from the force of a seat belt during a car accident.
  • This visible mark is a significant indicator of potential underlying injuries, including damage to internal organs like the mesentery, small intestine, or spine.

Management of seat belt-related injuries:

  • FAST is a quick and widely available method to detect intraperitoneal fluid or blood.
  • Computed tomography (CT) scanning offers significant advantages by identifying critical details such as extraluminal air or contrast leakage, which can guide the need for surgical intervention.
  • In cases where spinal injury is suspected, imaging of the entire spine should be conducted to rule out fractures, such as the Chance fracture commonly associated with seat belt injuries.
  • Treatment: Immediate laparotomy.

Seat belt syndrome describes the combination of the seat belt sign with associated internal injuries, such as abdominal organ damage or spinal fractures, particularly in the thoracolumbar region.

questions.text: A young patient in the first decade of life presents with grade II splenic injury with no active bleeding. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Conservative

Explanation:

  • In the case of a grade II splenic injury without active bleeding, the management is generally conservative.
  • This involves admission to the ICU for close monitoring, with repeated clinical assessments and possibly serial imaging to ensure there is no progression of injury or delayed bleeding.
  • The goal is to preserve the spleen, thus avoiding the complications associated with splenectomy, such as OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)

American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:

 
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularization of the spleen.

Management: Management of blunt trauma focuses on vigorous resuscitation.

  • For hemodynamically stable patients with minor splenic injuries, non-operative management (NOM) (conservative) is the preferred approach.
  • Splenectomy is recommended for severe injuries where bleeding control is prioritized over spleen preservation.
  • In cases with active bleeding, splenic angiography and embolization can be used to avoid splenectomy, but this should not delay laparotomy in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult male patient with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fistula in ano

Explanation:

  • A fistula in ano is a common cause of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening near the perianal region. It often results from a previous perianal abscess that has developed into a chronic fistulous tract.

Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

 

 

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.

  • Associated Conditions:

    • Crohn’s disease

    • Tuberculosis

    • Lymphogranuloma venereum

    • Actinomycosis

    • Rectal duplication

    • Foreign bodies

    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

 

Clinical features

  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.

  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess

  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Classifications:

  • Low-level fistulas open into the anal canal below the internal ring.

  • High-level fistulas open into the anal canal at or above the internal ring.

  • Simple fistula without extensions

  • Complex fistula with extensions.

Parks classification

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

Incorrect Options:

Hemorrhoids (Option A) typically present with bleeding during defecation but do not produce purulent discharge.

Pilonidal sinus (Option B) typically presents in the sacrococcygeal region and may involve purulent discharge, but is not commonly associated with blood-tinged drainage.

Perianal abscess (Option C) is an acute condition characterized by pain, swelling, and often fever, with purulent drainage, but would not typically cause intermittent discharge over time without other symptoms of infection.

questions.text: A barium swallow radiographic image of a woman with dysphagia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Achalasia

Explanation:

  • Achalasia is a disorder where the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, leading to a "bird-beak" appearance on a barium swallow, which is a classic finding in this condition. It causes difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and often results in a progressive esophageal dilation above the constricted LES.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumors.
