Distal Esophageal Spasm: This condition presents with characteristic "corkscrew" appearance on barium swallow, due to irregular, simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus.

Jackhammer Esophagus: This condition involves excessive peristalsis with very strong contractions, resulting in a tight, hypercontractile esophagus. It can cause dysphagia but has a different radiographic appearance.

questions.text: A patient underwent bronchoscopy, during the procedure a perforation occurred at 25 cm. Which structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario of perforation at 25 cm, the arch of the aorta is most likely to be damaged, as this is the region where the esophagus is compressed by the aorta and left bronchus.

Constrictions of Esophagus:

  • 0 cm - Incisor teeth (start of the esophagus).
  • 15 cm - Cricopharyngeal constriction (upper esophageal sphincter).
  • 25 cm - Aortic and bronchial constriction (due to the aorta and left bronchus).
  • 40 cm - Diaphragmatic constriction (at the esophageal hiatus, lower esophageal sphincter).

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resection and Anastomosis

Explanation:

The given image shows Resection and Anastomosis. This procedure involves the removal of a diseased or damaged segment of the bowel (resection) and then surgically joining the healthy ends of the remaining bowel (anastomosis). It's commonly performed in cases such as:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum with an unhealthy base
  • Transverse mesentery tear
  • Small intestinal duplication
  • Enterogenous cysts

 

Primary closure of perforation: Typically involves suturing a hole or perforation in the gastrointestinal tract, usually performed in cases of bowel perforation.

Ileostomy: A surgical procedure where the end of the ileum (small intestine) is brought to the surface of the abdomen to create an opening (stoma) for waste to exit. It may be used in cases of inflammatory bowel disease or after bowel resections.

Resection alone: This refers to the removal of part of the gastrointestinal tract without performing an anastomosis. It might be used when a portion of the bowel is removed due to a tumor, but reconnection isn't necessary or feasible at the time.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray shows intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strangulated Femoral Hernia

Explanation:

  • The swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle and the presence of intestinal obstruction are most likely indicative of a strangulated femoral hernia.
  • In an indirect inguinal hernia (Option B), the neck of the hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle.
  • In contrast, the neck of the hernia in a femoral hernia is located below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The femoral ring and canal are relatively rigid, which increases the risk of strangulation in these cases.

Femoral Hernia:

A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall.

  • Location: Appears as a bulge in the upper thigh, just below the groin crease.
  • Demographics: More common in women, especially older and overweight females.
  • Risk: Higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.
  • Symptoms:
    • Lump in the groin or upper thigh, which may be painless or painful.
    • Discomfort when standing, lifting, or straining.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain if the hernia becomes incarcerated or strangulated.

 

Adhesions (Option A): While adhesions can cause intestinal obstruction, they do not typically present with swelling.

Appendicular Mass (Option D): An appendicular mass can cause swelling but is usually located in the right iliac fossa, not lateral and below the pubic tubercle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. Radiological imaging shows a blind pouch at the level of the pharynx. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pulsion Diverticula

  • Pulsion diverticula in the esophagus due to increased pressure in the esophageal wall, leading to the outpouching of the mucosa through weakened areas. This can cause symptoms like dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation, and bad breath (halitosis). 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Achalasia Cardia: Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus where the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, causing difficulty in food passage and esophageal dilation. Symptoms include dysphagia, regurgitation, and sometimes weight loss. While lobar pneumonia could potentially result from aspiration due to dysphagia, it is not a defining feature of achalasia.

Option C - CA Esophagus (Esophageal Cancer): Esophageal cancer can lead to dysphagia, weight loss, and other symptoms. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not directly related to esophageal cancer. CA Esophagus does not explain these radiological findings.

Option D - GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease): GERD can cause symptoms like dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not typical consequences of GERD. These symptoms might arise due to chronic aspiration of stomach contents, leading to pneumonia, but GERD alone does not explain the presence of lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a smoker, presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue. He is known to be anemic and his sister had a history of endometrial cancer. The physician is considering appropriate colorectal cancer screening methods for this patient. Which screening method should be recommended for colorectal malignancy in this patient?

choices.text: Check for occult blood in stool

questions.solution:
Correct option B - Colonoscopy every 10 years:

  • Colonoscopy every 10 years is the recommended screening method for colorectal malignancy, especially in individuals with risk factors such as a family history of colorectal cancer and a personal history of anemia.
  • Colonoscopy allows for direct visualization of the entire colon and rectum, and it can both detect and remove precancerous growths (polyps) during the same procedure.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Barium enema: Barium enema is not a method for colorectal cancer screening.

Option C - Check for occult blood in stool:

  • Occult blood can be an indicator of gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • While fecal occult blood test (FOBT) is a screening method, it is not the most sensitive test and may require repeated testing.

Option D - Flexible sigmoidoscopy yearly:

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a screening method that involves examining the lower part of the colon and rectum using a flexible sigmoidoscope.
  • While it can be effective, it only examines a portion of the colon.
  • Colonoscopy provides a more comprehensive examination of the entire colon and is recommended every 10 years for colorectal cancer screening.

questions.text: What type of material is in the mesh used in Lichtenstein hernioplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Polypropylene: In Lichtenstein hernioplasty, polypropylene meshes are used to reinforce the abdominal wall and prevent hernia recurrence due to their long-term stability and minimal tissue reaction.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are not used as mesh material in Lichtenstein hernioplasty.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of abdominal pain, fever and vomiting. On examination, there is a palpable mass in right iliac fossa with leukocytosis. What is the management plan for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Ochsner-Sherren regime:

  • Ochsner-Sherren regime is for the management of acute appendicular mass.
  • It refers to a conservative approach involving antibiotics and bed rest for the treatment of an acute appendicular mass.
  • The strategy of this regime is based on the presumption that the inflammatory process is already localized and that inadvertent surgery is challenging and may be unsafe.
  • However, in many cases, surgical intervention is the preferred treatment.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Alvarado scoring: Alvarado scoring is a clinical scoring system used to assess the likelihood of acute appendicitis.

Option C - Laparoscopic appendectomy: Laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to remove the inflamed appendix.

Option D - Cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of the gallbladder.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension within 2 days of birth. An X-ray abdomen was performed which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Duodenal atresia

  • Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition in which there is a complete or partial obstruction of the lumen of the duodenum.
  • This obstruction can lead to bilious vomiting and abdominal distension shortly after birth.
  • X-ray image shows a characteristic "double bubble" sign, where there are two distinct air-filled bubbles in the abdomen, one representing the stomach and the other the dilated portion of the proximal duodenum, which is a typical radiological finding in duodenal atresia.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Pyloric stenosis:

  • Pyloric stenosis is a condition in which the muscle at the pylorus becomes abnormally thickened, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • It typically presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting and a palpable "olive-like" mass in the upper abdomen.
  • X-ray findings for pyloric stenosis usually include a "string sign" - a narrow pyloric channel.

Option C - Esophageal atresia:

  • Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition in which the esophagus does not develop properly.
  • This condition is associated with difficulty swallowing, drooling, choking and cyanosis.
  • X-ray shows an absence of air in the stomach and the presence of air in the proximal esophagus.

Option D - Gas in bowel: Gas in the bowel is a common finding in X-ray images of the abdomen and is present in normal conditions as well as various pathological conditions. It does not provide a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids and the manometry findings include uncoordinated or absent peristalsis with increased LES resting pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Achalasia cardia 

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus where there is impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), which leads to difficulty in moving food from the esophagus into the stomach.
  • This disorder often presents with symptoms like regurgitation of undigested food, difficulty swallowing solids and liquids and chest pain.

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents after undergoing a Billroth II gastrectomy operation and complains of symptoms suggestive of dumping syndrome, including vomiting and diarrhea occurring approximately 20 minutes after meals. What should be the initial management for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Reverse Billroth II to Billroth I

questions.solution:
Correct option B - Small frequent meals

  • Dumping syndrome is commonly seen after gastric surgery, such as Billroth II gastrectomy, where the pyloric valve is removed, leading to rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine.
  • Consuming smaller, more frequent meals can help slow down the rate of stomach emptying, reducing the severity of symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Low fat diet: A low fat diet might help to some extent, but the primary issue in dumping syndrome is the rapid emptying of the stomach, not necessarily the fat content of the food.

Option C - Insulin and protein: Insulin and protein are not used as management for dumping syndrome.

Option D - Reverse Billroth II to Billroth I:

  • Reversing the surgical procedure to convert a Billroth II to a Billroth I gastrectomy is a major surgical decision that is generally not the initial management choice for dumping syndrome.
  • Non-surgical approaches, like dietary modifications, are usually tried first.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is scheduled to undergo laparoscopic surgery. The surgical team plans to create a pneumoperitoneum to facilitate the procedure. Which gas is commonly used for creating the pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Carbon dioxide:

  • Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive surgical technique in which small incisions are made in the abdominal wall to insert a camera and surgical instruments. A pneumoperitoneum, which is the inflation of the abdominal cavity with gas, is created to create space for the surgeon to work and to provide a clear view of the surgical site. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the gas commonly used for creating the pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Helium: Helium is a noble gas that is lighter than air, but it is not commonly used for creating a pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. Helium is expensive and can lead to difficulties in accurately maintaining the desired pressure within the abdominal cavity.

Option B - Oxygen: Oxygen is not used for creating a pneumoperitoneum. It is not suitable for this purpose because it can support combustion, and the risk of fire or explosion would be a concern in a surgical setting.

Option C - Nitrogen: While nitrogen is an inert gas and is commonly found in the atmosphere, it is not the gas of choice for creating a pneumoperitoneum. Carbon dioxide is preferred over nitrogen due to its ability to be rapidly absorbed by the body if it enters the bloodstream, which reduces the risk of gas embolism.

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia, with a weight loss of approximately 6 kg over the last three months. He had a previous diagnosis of esophageal cancer and underwent treatment. What might be the cause of his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Esophageal cancer recurrence:

  • Given the patient's history of esophageal cancer, recurrence is a significant concern, especially with symptoms such as dysphagia and weight loss.
  • Esophageal cancer can recur, leading to the reemergence of symptoms

Incorrect choices:

Option B - Fibrosis:

  • Fibrosis refers to the development of scar tissue. While it could occur post-treatment, it might not directly explain the recurrence of dysphagia and weight loss.

Option C - Achalasia cardia:

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus, but it is less likely in this case, considering the patient's history of esophageal cancer.

Option D - GERD:

  • GERD could cause symptoms like dysphagia and weight loss, but it might not fully explain the history of esophageal cancer.

questions.text: What is the position of the appendix marked in red colour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retrocecal

Explanation:

  • The retrocecal position is one of the most common variations in the anatomical location of the appendix. In this position, the appendix is located behind the cecum, usually near the ileocecal valve.

Locations of the appendix and their presentations:

Location

Presentation

Retrocecal

May present with flank or back pain

Subcecal

Can mimic gynaecological disorders or urinary tract infection

Pre-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Post-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Paracecal

Can present with typical right lower quadrant pain

Subhepatic

Can be mistaken for cholecystitis

Pelvic

Can mimic symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease or ovarian pathology

questions.text: A surgeon examines a case of hernia and is able to retract the hernial sac but not its contents. Based on this examination, which type of hernia is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reduction en masse

Explanation:

  • Reduction en masse refers to the unintentional displacement or reduction of both the hernia sac and its contents into a deeper anatomical space, such as the preperitoneal or retroperitoneal space, which can occur during the attempted reduction of the hernia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Incarcerated hernia (Option A): In an incarcerated hernia, the lumen of the part of the colon within the hernial sac becomes obstructed by faeces. The fecal content, or scybalous material, can typically be indented with a finger, similar to putty. In this condition, the sac and its contents are firmly adhered to each other, meaning the contents are fixed within the sac. The hernia is always irreducible and often obstructed, though it may not necessarily be strangulated.

Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade) (Option C):

  • It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ.
  • It is more common in males, particularly the elderly and frequently occurs on the left side, where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix.
  • The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement.
  • Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect, but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac.

Maydl’s Hernia:

  • It involves two or more bowel loops that become incarcerated or strangulated within the hernia sac.
  • The obstructed loop is present intraperitoneally and easily missed during surgery.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with a complaint of per rectal bleeding. The surgeon suspects a possible colorectal pathology and wants to determine the most appropriate investigation for this patient. Which of the following options would be the best choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colonoscopy

Explanation:

  • Colonoscopy is the most appropriate investigation for a patient presenting with per rectal bleeding. It allows direct visualisation of the colon and rectum, helping to diagnose conditions such as colorectal cancer, diverticular disease, or inflammatory bowel disease, which could be causing the bleeding.

 

Incorrect Options:

CEA levels (Option B): While CEA levels can be useful for monitoring treatment response or detecting recurrence in patients with known colorectal cancer, they are not the primary diagnostic tool for the initial evaluation of per rectal bleeding.

CA-19-9 (Option C) is a tumour marker primarily associated with pancreatic and hepatobiliary malignancies, not colorectal pathology.

CECT (Contrast-enhanced CT scan) (Option D) may be used as an adjunct in specific cases or to assess extra-colonic findings, but it is not the first-line investigation for per rectal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frykman and Goldberg's

Explanation:

  • Frykman and Goldberg's procedure is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse. Instead, it is an abdominal approach used for rectal prolapse repair. This procedure involves a transabdominal posterior rectopexy and resection of the redundant left colon.

Operative management of Rectal Prolapse:

  • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilisation of the rectum.

Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option D)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's) (Option A)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction

Explanation:

  • The first vessel ligated during abdominoperineal resection is typically the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). High ligation of the IMA can damage the superior hypogastric nerve, leading to sympathetic dysfunction. This dysfunction can result in complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction due to disruption of the sympathetic nerve pathways that control these functions.

Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): APR, or the Miles procedure, is performed when the sphincters are infiltrated by tumour, requiring excision of the rectum, anus, and sphincter apparatus with a permanent colostomy. It's also used for elderly patients with distal rectal cancer and poor sphincter function.

  • Abdominal phase:
    • The IMA is divided.
    • The descending colon is mobilised and divided above the rectosigmoid junction.
    • The rectum is dissected to the levator ani, and a colostomy aperture is created.
  • Perineal phase:
    • A purse-string suture is placed around the anus, and an elliptical incision is made.
    • The anus, sphincter, and rectum are excised en bloc.
    • The specimen is removed, and the perineum is closed in layers.
  • The pelvic space can be filled with an omental pedicle or muscle flap if needed.
  • Wider excision may be performed to reduce the risk of recurrence (up to 33%).
  • Risks: APR has higher recurrence rates (up to 33%) due to specimen perforation and positive circumferential margins (up to 40%). A cylindrical resection helps avoid “coning” toward the rectum.
  • Complications:
    • Higher recurrence rates compared to low anterior resection
    • Anastomotic leaks/dehiscences
    • Necrosis of transposed colon
    • Bleeding
    • Strictures

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with right thigh pain after undergoing bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for an inguinal hernia. Which nerve entrapment is most likely responsible for this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Explanation:

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is commonly implicated in thigh pain following laparoscopic hernia repair. It can become entrapped during the surgical procedure, leading to meralgia paresthetica, a condition characterised by pain, tingling, or numbness along the outer thigh.
  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal (Option A) > Iliohypogastric (Option B) > Genital branch of GFN.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve(GFN).
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

Triangle of Doom

Triangle of Pain

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Vas deferens
  • Lateral: Gonadal vessels
  • Base: Fold of peritoneum
  • Apex: Deep inguinal ring

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Gonadal vessels
  • Lateral: Fold of peritoneum
  • Superior: Iliopubic tract

Content:

Iliac vessels are located behind the peritoneal fold.

Content: (Medial to Lateral)

  • Femoral nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

Clinical Significance:

Sharp dissection in this area risks damaging the iliac vessels, which can lead to severe bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications

Clinical Significance:

  • Potential risk of nerve damage if electrocautery is used.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most commonly injured nerve.

 

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterisation.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade (Option C)
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region, diagnosed as a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Conjoint tendon

Explanation:

  • The conjoint tendon, created by the union of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, forms the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and contributes to the posterior wall of the superficial inguinal ring. Weakness in this structure can result in a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Pectineal ligament (Option A): The pectineal ligament, though it contributes to the inguinal canal's floor, is not directly involved in the formation of a direct inguinal hernia. Its weakening alone does not typically cause this condition.

Reflected part of the inguinal ligament (Option C) helps form the inguinal canal's floor, but it is not the primary structure responsible for the weakness leading to a direct inguinal hernia. The weakness is mainly related to the conjoint tendon.

Lacunar ligament (Option D): The lacunar ligament, part of the inguinal ligament, contributes to the inguinal canal's floor but does not play a central role in the development of a direct inguinal hernia. The weakness of the conjoint tendon is the key factor here.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal polyp and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. The child is diagnosed with a juvenile rectal polyp. Which of the following best describes the polyp in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hamartoma

Explanation:

  • Juvenile rectal polyps are hamartomatous in nature, typically solitary but can sometimes appear in multiples.
  • These polyps are most commonly found in children under 5 years of age and usually present with rectal bleeding.
  • The condition is associated with mutations in SMAD 2, SMAD 4, and BMPR1A. Extra-intestinal features may include digital clubbing and vascular malformations.
  • The histological appearance of a juvenile rectal polyp is shown below:

 

 

Adenomas (Option A) are benign tumours that originate from glandular tissue. While adenomas can occur in the rectum, they are rare in children.

Choristoma (Option B) are ectopic tissues found in abnormal locations. They are rare in the rectum and are not typically associated with juvenile rectal polyps.

Carcinoma (Option D) refers to malignant tumours that arise from epithelial cells. It is highly unlikely for a 5-year-old child to develop carcinoma, making this an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Feeding jejunostomy

Explanation:

  • Ingesting strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide can lead to significant damage to the esophagus, resulting in a condition called caustic esophagitis. A feeding jejunostomy enables nutrition to bypass the esophagus entirely, allowing it time to heal.

Corrosive injury to the esophagus occurs when it is exposed to acids or alkalis.

Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Alkali causes liquefaction, saponification, and thrombosis of vessels, leading to fibrosis and stricture.
  • Acid causes intense pylorospasm, antral pooling, coagulation necrosis, and eschar formation.

Acute Phase Management
  • Neutralization: vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid
  • Early endoscopy to assess severity and extent
  • Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation

Management by Burn Degree

1st Degree Burns:

  • 48 hours observation; oral feeds resumed once saliva is swallowed painlessly
  • Regular follow-up endoscopy at 1st, 2nd, and 8th months to identify stricture

2nd & 3rd Degree Burns:

  • Fluid therapy, antibiotics, nutrition, PPIs and aerosolised steroids and resuscitation
  • Fiberoptic-guided airway intubation/tracheostomy, if necessary.
  • Endoscopic esophageal stenting, jejunostomy for feeding.
  • Laparoscopy for evaluation; laparotomy in unstable patients
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness.
  • Consider re-exploration after 36-48 hours if necessary.
  • Regular endoscopic dilatation for stricture
  • Use of various dilators (e.g., balloon, Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow) for esophageal dilatation.

Surgical Considerations
  • Esophageal resection is technically difficult; bypass may be preferred
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • A colonic conduit may be used if the stomach is diseased
  • Multiple strictures may require esophageal resection and colonic transposition

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis?

choices.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
USG is the gold standard investigation for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles

Explanation:

  • Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles.

Clinical Presentation
  • Typical onset: 3 to 6 weeks of age
  • Symptoms:
    • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting (Option A ruled out)
    • Visible gastric peristalsis
    • Palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen (hypertrophied pylorus), best felt from the left side
      • Test feed: Gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric ‘tumor’ is palpable as an ‘olive’ in the right upper quadrant.
    • Dyselectrolytemias-
      • Hypochloremia
      • Hypokalemia due to persistent vomiting
      • Metabolic alkalosis. (Option D ruled out)

Ultrasound (Gold Standard)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Characteristic "doughnut sign" indicating thickened pyloric muscle
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • "Cervix sign" on long-axis view
    • "Target sign" on short-axis view

Barium Meal (Less Common)

Can assist in diagnosis but is less accurate than ultrasound, it reveals:

  • "String sign": Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
  • "Railroad track sign": Two thin lines of contrast indicating mild narrowing
  • "Double track sign": Similar to railroad track sign, indicating thickened muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intersphincteric

Explanation:

  • The intersphincteric type is the most common form of Anorectal Fistula (Fistula-in-Ano).
  • A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Classifications:

  • Low-level fistulas open into the anal canal below the internal ring.
  • High-level fistulas open into the anal canal at or above the internal ring.
  • Simple fistula without extensions
  • Complex fistula with extensions.

Parks classification:

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%) (Option A)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%) (Option B ruled out)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%) (Option C ruled out)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: During an endoscopy, when a constriction is detected at the esophageal junction approximately 25 cm from the incisor, what is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • The constriction at the esophageal junction, about 25 cm from the incisor, is likely caused by the arch of the aorta, where the Esophagus passes behind the aorta and left main bronchus, leading to a physiological narrowing.

Physical Narrowing

  • The esophagus has three relatively narrow sections, with endoscopic measurements from the incisors.
  • They are:
    • Cricopharyngeus muscle (upper oesophageal sphincter)
    • Where the left main bronchus and aorta cross the oesophagus
    • Esophagogastric junction (lower oesophageal sphincter).

 

Inferior vena cava (Option A) runs parallel to the aorta in the abdomen and does not cross the esophagus in the thoracic cavity, so it does not cause constriction at the esophageal junction.

Right bronchus (Option C) crosses the esophagus lower in the thoracic cavity and does not cause constriction at the 25 cm level, where the esophagus is more closely related to the left bronchus and arch of the aorta.

Diaphragmatic opening (Option D) is located around 40 cm from the incisors, lower than the 25 cm mark, and is not involved in constriction at this level.

questions.text: A homosexual man presents with painful defecation and a protruding mass from the anal canal. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What is the appropriate course of action for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Combined chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • Combined chemoradiation, involving chemotherapy (fluorouracil and mitomycin C) and radiation, is the standard treatment for localized squamous cell carcinoma of the anus, preserving anal function and improving local control and survival.

Anal Canal Carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection: Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)
  • Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN): A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients)
  • Sexual Practices: Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.
  • History of Other Genital Neoplasia: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
  • Extensive Anogenital Condylomata: The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection

Clinical features
  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Palpable Mass
  • Pruritus (Itching)
  • Discharge
  • Incontinence
  • Fistulation (anterior tumour extension in women can create a fistula between the anus and vagina).
  • Appearance:
    • Anal margin tumours: Often resemble malignant ulcers with raised, hardened edges.
    • Anal canal tumours: Typically palpable as irregular, hardened, and tender ulcerated areas.
  • Lymph Node Involvement: Enlarged lymph nodes in the perirectal or groin regions may indicate cancer spread.

Investigations

  • Biopsy from the Anal Region: The primary diagnostic test to confirm the presence of carcinoma.
  • FNAC of Inguinal Nod (assess metastasis).
  • USG Abdomen (check for any spread of the disease).
  • MRI of the Perineum (assess the extent of the tumour).
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Assess the upper extent of the tumour within the anal canal.

Management

  • Chemoradiation (Nigro regimen): The preferred treatment modality for carcinoma of the anal canal. (Option C)
    • Chemotherapy Drugs: Commonly used drugs include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), bleomycin, vincristine, and adriamycin.
    • Radiotherapy: Often used alone in advanced cases where the tumour is not resectable.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) with Colostomy: For persistent or recurrent disease after combined modality therapy (CMT), or for cases where the tumor does not respond to chemoradiation. (Option B ruled out)
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Involves using 5-FU, cisplatin, and mitomycin C before surgery to shrink the tumour.

 

Chemotherapy (Option A) alone is not the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anus; chemoradiation is preferred for better local control and survival.

Wide local excision (Option D) is not the standard treatment for anal cancer, as chemoradiation is more effective in preserving function and reducing recurrence. Surgery is only considered if chemoradiation fails.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MRI

Explanation:

  • The gold standard investigation in Fistula-in-Ano is MRI.

Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Investigation

  • MRI: Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice) (Option D)
  • Endoscopic Ultrasound: It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.
  • Fistulography: An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel. (1st investigation) (Option A ruled out)
  • Examination Under Anesthesia: Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.
  • Fistula Probe: A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.
  • Anoscopy: A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy.

Management:

Fistulotomy

  • Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.
  • Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

  • Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.
  • Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

  • Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.
  • Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

  • Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.
  • Effective for certain fistula configurations.

 

USG (Ultrasonography) (Option B) is useful for assessing superficial fistulas but is limited in evaluating deep or complex ones, lacking the detailed imaging of surrounding structures that MRI provides.

CECT (Contrast Enhanced Computed Tomography) (Option B) is less ideal for fistula-in-ano due to lower soft tissue contrast compared to MRI, which provides superior detail and accuracy in evaluating fistula anatomy.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has the highest risk of causing the recurrence of duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Highly selective vagotomy

Explanation:

  • Highly Selective Vagotomy (also known as Parietal Cell Vagotomy or Proximal Gastric Vagotomy) has the highest risk of causing the recurrence of duodenal ulcers.
  • It is the procedure that best preserves the vagal innervation of the gastric antrum and pylorus.
  • It divides only the vagus nerves supplying the acid-producing portion of the stomach within the corpus and fundus, so there is no need for routine drainage procedures.

 

Characteristic

Truncal Vagotomy

(Option C ruled out)

Truncal Vagotomy with Antrectomy

(Option D ruled out)

Selective Vagotomy

(Option A ruled out)

Highly Selective Vagotomy

(Option B)

Nerves Divided

Left and right vagus above hepatic and celiac branches

Truncal vagotomy plus removal of the antrum

Main right and left vagus distal to celiac and hepatic branches

Only nerves to the acid-producing portion (all branches to the fundus and body) of the stomach

Drainage Procedure

Usually required

Not applicable

Required

Not required

Acid Reduction

~50%

~85%

<50%

Variable

Ulcer Recurrence

2-7%

1%

5-10%

2-10%%

Significant side effects

10-20%

10-20%

10-20%

<5%

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel; after a few months, she presents with easy fatigability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anaemia. Resection of all of the following can cause this, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Duodenum

Explanation:

Resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause Macrocytic Anemia, as it typically leads to iron deficiency anaemia, which is microcytic and hypochromic.

  • Causes:

Folic acid Deficiency

Vitamin B12 Deficiency
  • Site of folate absorption - Jejunum (Option A ruled out)
  • Seen in: Alcoholics, pregnancy
  • Causes neural tube defects
  • Neurological symptoms are not seen
  • Normal methylmalonic acid
  • High homocysteine
  • FIGLU test positive
  • Site of B12 absorption - Ileum (Option C ruled out)
  • Seen in: Vegetarians, pregnancy, Diphyllobothrium latum infection
  • Neurological manifestation: Subacute combined degeneration
  • High methylmalonic acid
  • High homocysteine

 

Vitamin B12 Absorption and Transport:

  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum.
  • Haptocorrin, secreted by the salivary gland, binds to B12 in the stomach and enters the duodenum.
  • Haptocorrin is separated from B12 by pancreatic enzymes and binds to IF.
  • Absorbed B12 is transported by transcobalamin II.
  • It is stored primarily in the liver and has a large reserve capacity to last several years.
  • Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for:
    • Conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
    • Methyl malonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

Stomach (Option D) produces intrinsic factors, which are necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the ileum. Resection of the stomach, particularly in cases like gastrectomy, can cause vitamin B12 deficiency and subsequent macrocytic anaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute cholecystitis is false?

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Gold standard investigation is CT scan

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gold standard investigation for acute cholecystitis is the HIDA (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid) Scan, not a CT scan.
  • Non-visualization of the gallbladder on a HIDA scan indicates cystic duct obstruction, a key characteristic of acute cholecystitis, thus making it a diagnostic feature. 

Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis (2013/2018)

Local Signs of Inflammation:
  • Murphy's sign (Option B ruled out)
  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain/ tenderness or a palpable mass.

Systemic Signs of Inflammation:
  • Fever
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated WBC (Option C ruled out)

Imaging Findings:
  • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm) (Option A ruled out)
  • Pericholecystic fluid,
  • Ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rip stein's procedure

 

Explanation:

The image depicts Rectal Prolapse, and Ripstein’s procedure, a surgical treatment, is not a perineal approach.

  • It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal.
  • Management of Rectal prolapse:
    • Non-Operative Management
  • Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema.
  • Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms.

  • Operative Management

    • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilisation of the rectum.

 

Aspect
Abdominal Rectopexy
Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein (Option A)
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option B ruled out)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's) (Option D ruled out)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C ruled out)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: A patient who had grade 3 splenic trauma was managed conservatively in the ICU. Which of the following signs on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery?

choices.text: Hemoglobin falls from 12 mg/dL to 10 mg/dL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma managed conservatively, the presence of pneumoperitoneum on day 2 is a critical sign of an Acute Abdomen, typically indicating a perforated viscus requiring urgent surgical intervention.

  • It refers to the signs and symptoms of abdominal pain and tenderness.
  • It represents an underlying surgical problem that requires prompt diagnosis and surgical treatment.
  • Causes:

 

Surgical Causes

Non-surgical Causes

Endocrine and Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria
  • Addisonian crisis
  • Diabetic crisis
  • Hereditary Mediterranean fever
  • Uremia

Hematologic

  • Acute leukemia
  • Sickle cell crisis

Toxins and drugs

  • Black widow spider poisoning
  • Lead poisoning
  • Other heavy metal poisoning
  • Narcotic withdrawal

Hemorrhage

  • Aortoduodenal fistula after aortic vascular graft
  • Arteriovenous malformation of the gastrointestinal tract
  • Bleeding gastrointestinal diverticulum
  • Hemorrhagic pancreatitis
  • Intestinal ulceration
  • Leaking or ruptured arterial aneurysm
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Solid organ trauma
  • Spontaneous splenic rupture

Infections

  • Appendicitis
  • Cholecystitis
  • Diverticulitis
  • Hepatic abscess
  • Meckel diverticulitis
  • Psoas abscess

Ischemia

  • Buerger’s disease
  • Ischemic colitis
  • Mesenteric thrombosis or embolism
  • Ovarian torsion
  • Strangulated hernia
  • Testicular torsion

Obstruction

  • Cecal volvulus
  • Gastrointestinal malignancy
  • Incarcerated hernias
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Intussusception
  • Sigmoid volvulus
  • Small bowel obstruction

Perforation

  • Boerhaave syndrome
  • Perforated diverticulum
  • Perforated gastrointestinal cancer
  • Perforated gastrointestinal ulcer

Hemoglobin falls from 12 mg/dL to 10 mg/dL (Option A): A mild drop in hemoglobin may indicate blood loss but doesn't necessarily require surgery. Conservative management can continue if the patient remains stable, with surgery considered only for significant drops or signs of instability.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option B): While serious, extraperitoneal bladder rupture is not directly related to grade 3 splenic trauma and is usually managed conservatively with catheter drainage. Surgery is reserved for intraperitoneal rupture or severe complications.

Air in gallbladder (Pneumobilia) (Option D) indicates emphysematous cholecystitis, which may require surgery but is not as urgent as pneumoperitoneum, typically linked to a perforated organ and peritonitis.

questions.text:
A female patient was diagnosed with gastric cancer. On immunohistopathology, the biopsy sample was positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. What is the diagnosis?

LCA - Leucocyte common antigen

GIST - Gastrointestinal stromal tumors

SCC - Squamous cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GIST

 

Explanation:

The biopsy findings showing positive CD117 (also known as c-Kit) and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are characteristic of Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs).

  • Common Locations:
    • Stomach (most common)
    • Small Intestine
    • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).
  • Origin: The Interstitial cells of Cajal (Gastric pacemaker cells)

  • Immunohistochemistry Markers for GISTs: (Option A)

 

Category

Marker

Expression in GISTs

Significance
 

Old Markers

CD117 (c-KIT)

Expressed in approximately 97% of GISTs

Crucial for diagnosis

CD34

Expressed in 70% GISTs

Associated with hematopoietic progenitor cells

SMA

Some GISTs show positivity

Less common compared to CD117 and CD34



 

New Markers

PDGFRA

Mutations found in approximately 5-10% of GISTs

Additional diagnostic marker

DOG1

Expressed in many GISTs, including those negative for CD117

Alternative diagnostic tool
  • Clinical features:
    • GI Bleed (most common)
    • Abdominal Pain
    • Weightloss
    • Large abdominal mass- it arises from the submucosa - hence, it is extraluminal- but expands and compresses the mucosa
    • Metastasis to liver
  • Carney’s Triad:

It is a rare syndrome characterised by the presence of three specific tumours: gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs), extra-adrenal paragangliomas, and pulmonary chondromas.

 

Adenocarcinoma (Option B) is a type of cancer that originates in epithelial cells and typically stains positive for cytokeratin, which is absent in this case. The absence of cytokeratin makes adenocarcinoma unlikely in this patient.

 

Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option C) expresses LCA (Leucocyte Common Antigen), a marker for hematologic malignancies, especially lymphomas. Since the biopsy is negative for LCA, Hodgkin’s lymphoma can be excluded as a diagnosis.


SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) (Option D) expresses cytokeratin, a marker for epithelial differentiation. Since the biopsy is negative for cytokeratin, SCC is unlikely.

questions.text: A female patient is planned for cholecystectomy. Which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery?

choices.text: Earlier return to normal physiological function
Longer duration of stay in hospital

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Longer duration of stay in hospital

 

Explanation:

Longer hospital stay is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

Advantages of laproscopic surgery:

 

  • Less postoperative pain (Option A ruled out)
  • Better cosmesis (Option B ruled out)
  • Earlier return to normal physiology (Option C ruled out)
  • Shorter hospital stays (Option D)
  • Fewer intraoperative adhesions are created.
  • Better perception of anatomy as the image is often magnified.

questions.text: Severe, intractable pain in advanced rectum cancers is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

Advanced cancers invading outside the mesorectum may infiltrate the prostate or bladder anteriorly or the sacral plexus posteriorly, giving rise to severe, intractable pain.

 

Clinical Features of Rectal Carcinoma:

  • Commonly seen in >55 years of age
  • Early Symptoms:
    • Bleeding per rectum: The most common early symptom, often bright red and painless, which can be mistaken for hemorrhoidal bleeding.
    • Tenesmus: It is an important early symptom. It is the feeling of incomplete evacuation, often present with lower rectal tumours, leading to frequent attempts to pass stool or gas.
    • Diarrhoea: Early morning diarrhoea may occur.
  • Late Symptoms:
    • Constipation can develop with rectosigmoid junction tumours.
    • Colicky pain may indicate obstruction and advanced cancers may cause severe pain due to invasion of nearby structures (prostate or bladder anteriorly or the sacral plexus posteriorly). (Option D)
    • Weight loss indicates metastatic disease.
  • Abdominal Examination Findings:
    • Early cases may be normall while obstructing tumours can show signs of subacute bowel obstruction.
    • Palpable liver enlargement may indicate liver metastases, and cachexia can be present.
    • Ascites may be found in cases of peritoneal spread.
  • Rectal Examination Findings:
    • The tumour is palpable within 7-8 cm of the anal verge, appearing as a raised, hard mass. If ulcerated, it may present as a depression with everted edges.
    • Mobility and distance from the anal sphincter complex are important for assessing resectability and surgical planning.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dilated esophagus with a "bird beak" appearance, suggesting Achalasia Cardia, where 24-hour pH monitoring is unnecessary as the condition primarily involves structural and motility issues, not acid reflux.

 

Achalasia Cardia

Definition

Progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the oesophagal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry (Option C ruled out)

  • Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the oesophagus.
  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram) (Option A ruled out)

  • Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy (Option B ruled out)

  • Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris; it is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

Management

Pharmacological Treatments

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (reduce LES pressure)
  • Nitrates (relax the LES)
  • 5'-Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors (increase cyclic GMP to lower LES pressure)
  • Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections (temporarily paralyse LES muscles).

Non-Surgical Interventions

  • Bougie/Balloon Dilatation (ruptures LES muscle fibres to reduce pressure).

Surgical Treatments

  • Laparoscopic Heller's Cardiomyotomy (Most common)
    • The incision in the LES muscle to reduce pressure.
    • It is often combined with a fundoplication.
  • Partial Fundoplication
    • Prevents reflux; options include Dor or Toupet fundoplication.
  • Esophagectomy
    • Surgical removal of the esophagus (severe cases).

Endoscopic Treatments

  • Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM): A newer Minimally invasive procedure involving dissection of LES muscle fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following causes maximum malnutrition?
questions.solution:
• Duodenal Fistulas can cause maximum malnutrition, as the duodenum is crucial for nutrient absorption, including proteins, fats, carbohydrates, vitamins, and minerals.
  • It occurs as a complication of:
    • Gastric resection
    • Duodenal resection
    • Biliary tract procedures
    • Pancreatic resections
    • Trauma
    • Perforated peptic ulcers
    • Cancer.
  • There is a direct connection between the duodenum and an abnormal opening, causing significant nutrient loss and malnutrition.

 

(A) The smaller duodenal fistula was repaired over a t-tube; (B) The larger fistula was closed with interrupted sutures. (C) Pyloric exclusion; (D) Jejuno-jejunostomy following segmental resection of jejunal fistula; (E) Feeding jejunostomy

 

Pancreatic fistula (Option A) leads to the loss of digestive enzymes, but the body can adapt to some extent, causing less severe malnutrition than a duodenal fistula, where nutrient absorption is directly impaired.

 

Distal ileal fistula (Option C) affects the absorption of bile salts and vitamin B12, but it doesn’t impact the absorption of a wide range of nutrients like the duodenum, which is responsible for absorbing most nutrients from digested food.


Colonic fistula (Option D) mainly affects water and electrolyte absorption, leading to dehydration or imbalances, but it has less impact on overall nutrient absorption compared to a duodenal fistula, which disrupts early nutrient uptake.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves would be involved if a patient experiences a loss of sensations over the root of the penis after undergoing open hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
• The loss of sensation at the root of the penis after open hernia surgery likely involves the Ilioinguinal Nerve.
  • It originates from the first lumbar nerve and passes through the inguinal canal.
  • Supplies: Sensory innervation to the upper medial thigh, the root of the penis, and mons pubis in males.
  • During open hernia surgery, this nerve can be damaged or irritated, resulting in a loss of sensation in the structures.

Hernia Surgery

  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve. (Option B)
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve.
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

 

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterization.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

 

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option A) provides sensory innervation to the lower abdomen and the upper part of the thigh, but it does not innervate the root of the penis. It is less likely to be involved in loss of sensation at the root of the penis.

 

Genitofemoral nerve (Option C) does provide sensation to the skin of the genital area; it mainly innervates the scrotum and labia, not specifically the root of the penis. It is less likely to be affected in this case.


Medial cutaneous nerve to the thigh (Option D) provides sensation to the inner thigh, but it has no direct involvement in the sensory innervation of the penis. Therefore, it wouldn't cause loss of sensation over the root of the penis after surgery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism presents to the hospital. A splenectomy is planned for this child. All the following vaccines are recommended before splenectomy except?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not recommended before Splenectomy, as Salmonella typhi is not an encapsulated organism and is not directly linked to the increased infection risk after the procedure.

Reason for vaccination:

  • Normal function of the spleen: Phagocytosis of encapsulated organisms.
  • Post-splenectomy septicemia is majorly due to encapsulated organisms S. pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides, Haemophilus influenzae, or Escherichia coli.

Vaccine recommendations for asplenic patients:

Vaccination

Children

Adults (age 19 and older)

Pneumococcal (Option A ruled out)

  • PCV13 followed by PVC13 8 weeks later.
  • PPSV23 8 weeks later.
  • Repeat PPSV23 at 5 years
  • PCV13 followed by PPSV23 8 weeks later
  • Repeat PPSV23 every 5 years

Meningococcal (Option D ruled out)

MenACWY series AND MenB series
  • MenACWY or MPSV4 2 months apart
  • Repeat MenACWY every 5 years AND MenB series once.

Haemophilus influenzae type B (Option C ruled out)

Hib once if 15 months or older and previously not vaccinated

Hib once
  • Time for vaccination:
    • Ideally- 10-12 weeks before surgery
    • At Least 2 weeks before an elective surgery
    • Emergency splenectomy- At discharge or 14 days after surgery, whichever is first.
  • CDC immunisation guidelines for 2020 also recommend tetanus (Tdap or Td), human papillomavirus (HPV), measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR), varicella, zoster, influenza, hepatitis A (hep A) and hepatitis B (hep B), and meningococcal vaccines.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about psoas abscess are true?


	Fluctuant swelling in the hip
	Cold abscess can develop from Pott’s abscess
	Pain on the passive extension of the hip joint is seen
	It develops more commonly through the hematogenous route in immunocompromised patients and elderly.
questions.solution:
All of the above statements regarding Psoas Abscess (also known as Retroperitoneal Abscess) are correct.

  • It is an abscess of the retroperitoneum.
  • Causes:
    • Tuberculosis (TB) of the spine (Pott’s disease). (Statement 2)
    • Secondary to direct spread of infection from the inflamed digestive or urinary tract (with or without perforation).
    • Advanced Crohn’s disease.
    • Haematogenous spread from an occult source (immunocompromised patients) (Statement 4)
    • Intravenous drug misuse.
  • Presentation:
    • A fluctuant swelling in the hip region with localised swelling and inflammation. (Statement 1)
    • Pain and discomfort in the hip area. (Statement 3)
  • Imaging:
    • X-ray: Intact right psoas muscle shadow, but the left psoas shadow is absent, with a large radiopacity in the left lumbar region.
    • CT Scan: A large bilobed, peripherally enhancing collection in the upper two-thirds of the left psoas muscle, extending into the left pararenal space, displacing the left kidney superiorly, with thickening of the lateroconal fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
• In Meckel's Diverticulum, the most frequently found ectopic tissues are gastric and pancreatic tissues.
  • Persistent remnant of the Vitello-intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct.

Meckel's Diverticulum

Clinical features
  • Most common ectopic mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum is Gastric > Pancreatic > Colonic (Option A) (Option B, C ruled out)
  • The most common symptom in children is gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Ulcers are formed in the surrounding area due to acid secreted from the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum, which causes bleeding.
  • The most common symptom in adults is abdominal pain.
  • Complications: Volvulus, intestinal obstruction, intussusceptions, diverticulitis and perforation.

Investigations
  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan: Absorbed by the ectopic gastric mucosa, allowing for visualisation.
  • Plain abdominal radiography, CT abdomen, and ultrasonography are seldom useful.
  • Endoscopy: Helpful in false-negative cases, but not the investigation of choice.

Management

  • Healthy base (no induration or ulceration): Diverculectomy (excision of the diverticulum only) + anastomosis.
  • Unhealthy base (ulceration, presence of gastric mucosa): Resection of the small bowel with the diverticulum + anastomosis.
  • Incidentally detected during an elective surgery: Diverculectomy.


Thyroid and lung (Option D) tissue are extremely rare in Meckel’s diverticulum. These tissues are not typically associated with diverticular formations in the small intestine.

questions.text: What is true about gall bladder carcinoma?

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Gallstones and gallbladder cancer are easily distinguished clinically
Median survival is less than 6 months

questions.solution:
Gallbladder Cancer is a deadly disease with a median survival of less than 6 months, a 5-year survival rate of 50% for localised cases (with chemotherapy), and 2-5% for those with distant metastasis.

 

Gallbladder Cancer

Etiology

  • Gallstones
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction
  • Cholesterosis of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps
  • Porcelain gallbladder
  • Infections and inflammatory conditions
    • Chronic typhoid carriers
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections
  • Other factors:
    • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
    • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
    • Nitrosamines
    • Carcinogens

Clinical features

  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases (Option C ruled out)
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage) (Option B ruled out)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage) (Option A ruled out)

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnostic Imaging
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging and Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Management
  • Early disease:
    • For disease confined to the mucosa, if there is negative cystic duct margin and no recurrence on imaging- No further treatment
  • For transmural disease- Radical en bloc resection of gallbladder fossa, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes.
  • Advanced Cancer:
    • Non-operative palliative care.
    • Endoscopic/percutaneous methods to relieve obstructive jaundice.
  • Adenocarcinoma:
    • Early-stage limited to mucosa:
  • No additional treatment is required if imaging shows no recurrence.
  • Beyond mucosa:
    • Extensive surgery involving gallbladder fossa, a portion of the liver, and nearby lymph nodes.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone appendectomy 2 days ago presents with severe abdominal pain. On exploration, there is a collection of blood in the abdomen. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during surgery?
questions.solution:
The appendicular artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery, supplies the appendix, and if not properly ligated during an Appendectomy, can lead to postoperative bleeding and blood collection in the abdomen.

 

Steps during Open Appendectomy:

Right colic artery (Option B) supplies the ascending colon, not the appendix. It is not typically involved in an appendectomy, so failure to ligate it would not cause bleeding related to the appendix.

Superior rectal artery (Option C) is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies the rectum. It has no role in the blood supply to the appendix, and failure to ligate it would not result in bleeding from an appendectomy.

Superior mesenteric artery (Option D) supplies the small intestine, cecum, and parts of the colon, but it does not directly supply the appendix. Ligating this artery would affect a broader region but is not specific to preventing bleeding during appendectomy.

questions.text:
What should be the subsequent step in managing a 32-year-old male patient who comes to the surgical emergency department with a 2-day history of peptic ulcer disease, experiencing abdominal pain, bloating, and difficulty passing stools?


	IV fluids
	CECT abdomen
	Exploratory laparotomy
	Upper GI endoscopy


Below is the provided X-ray film image
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, bloating, difficulty passing stools, and air under the diaphragm suggest intestinal perforation, requiring IV fluids for stabilisation and exploratory laparotomy for surgical intervention.

 

Complications of duodenal ulcer:

Duodenal ulcer perforation
  • Common with anterior duodenal ulcers.
  • Presents with an acute abdomen with sudden-onset, severe epigastric pain, rebound tenderness, and air under the diaphragm in the radiograph. (Option B)
  • Management:
    • Non-surgical:
      • Nil per-oral
      • IV antibiotics and PPIs
    • Surgical:
      • Initial empirical antibiotic treatment.
      • The perforation is approached by a small upper midline incision
      • Perforations <1cm are closed primarily and buttressed with a well-vascularized omentum
      • Larger perforations & with fibrotic edges: Modified Graham's Repair or Omental Patch Repair.
      • The vascularized pedicle of the greater omentum is patched over the defect.

Bleeding duodenal ulcer
  • A posterior duodenal ulcer is the one that usually bleeds.
  • It is due to the involvement of the gastroduodenal artery.
  • This leads to hematemesis, melena or both i.e., an upper GI bleed.
  • Bleeding is commonly associated with intake of NSAIDs.
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic: Done to find the bleeding source and manage bleeds endoscopically. Injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue are the methods used. (with or without adrenaline injection).
    • Angiographic management: If endoscopic management fails.
    • Surgical management:
      • Exposure to the ulcer and ligation of the duodenum are the principles here.
      • Duodenotomy
      • Ligation of the bleeding vessel with truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty

Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO)
  • Acute inflammation of the duodenum or pylorus leads to mechanical obstruction with a functional gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Presents with nausea, early satiety, vomiting, loss of weight, and anorexia.

Hourglass deformity

It is seen in chronic gastric ulcers with scarring and fibrosis.

Pyloric stenosis

It is seen in cases of chronic ulcers, which lead to stricture and constriction of the pylorus.

 

CECT abdomen (Statement B) can help assess the extent of the perforation, but it is not the first step in this emergency scenario. The presence of air under the diaphragm on the X-ray already suggests perforation and surgical intervention is the priority.


Upper GI endoscopy (Statement D) can diagnose peptic ulcers in the case of a perforation, but an immediate exploratory laparotomy is needed to repair the hole and prevent further complications. Endoscopy is not suitable for this emergency.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement regarding gastric carcinoma:


	It is mostly hereditary
	E-cadherin adhesion defect is seen in diffuse types of gastric CA.
	Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA.
	Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis.
questions.solution:
B and C statements are correct regarding Gastric Carcinoma.

Category

Risk factors

Diet

High-salt foods (e.g., salted and smoked meats), low intake of fruits and vegetables

N-nitroso compounds are formed from nitrates in high-salt and smoked foods, Similar to tobacco smoke

Lifestyle habits

Smoking, alcohol, poor food preparation (smoked, salted), lack of refrigeration, contaminated drinking water, low socioeconomic status

Infectious Causes

H- pylori infection: M/c infectious cause of gastric cancer.

Mechanism: Chronic inflammation leading to atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma

Polyps
  • Adenomatous polyps (risk of malignancy)
  • In multiple polyps, the largest one is excised, and biopsy from others is taken.

Hereditary factors
  • E-cadherin (CDH1) gene mutation (hereditary diffuse gastric cancer) (Statement B)
  • Hereditary cancer syndromes
  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome

Medications

Proton pump inhibitors (long-term use creates low-acid environment achlorhydria; Risk for H. pylori colonisation)

Other risk factors

Gastric ulcers, pernicious anaemia (achlorhydria), obesity, Epstein-Barr virus, prior abdominal irradiation (for testicular cancer or Hodgkin’s lymphoma), prior gastric surgery, male sex

Wnt signalling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric carcinoma (Statement C): The Wnt signalling pathway plays a crucial role in developing intestinal-type gastric carcinoma. Dysregulation of this pathway can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and tumour formation.

Protective factors of Gastric carcinoma:

  • Fruits and vegetables, especially citrus fruits, help decrease the risk of the disease.
  • Exercise helps control the weight and improves muscle mass and overall health.
  • Antioxidant supplements help, too. ( beta carotene, vitamin C, vitamin A, selenium)
  • Cessation of smoking is also necessary.

It is mostly hereditary (Statement A): There are certain genetic factors that can increase the risk of developing gastric cancer, but the majority of cases are not directly linked to hereditary factors.

Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis (Statement D): The depth of cancer invasion, known as tumour staging, is an important prognostic factor in gastric carcinoma.

questions.text:
A patient presented with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and was found to have pancreatic necrosis. Which of the following are included in the management of the condition?


	Antibiotics IV
	IV fluids
	Culture
	MRI
	Assisted drainage
	Laparotomy
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 2, 3 and 5 are included in the management of Pancreatic Necrosis.

  • It refers to a diffuse or focal area of non-viable parenchyma.
  • Pathogenesis: It involves peripancreatic fat lysis, leading to an acute necrotic collection (ANC) with fluid and necrotic material, developing a defined inflammatory capsule, and evolving into walled-off necrosis (WON).
  • Types: Sterile (initial stage) and Infected.
  • CECT scan: An absence of parenchymal enhancement.
  • Culture and Sensitivity: Aspirated fluid is sent for culture and sensitivity. (Statement 3)
  • Management:
    • Supportive measures (IV fluids and stabilisation) (Statement 2)
    • Sterile necrotic material should not be drained or interfered with.
    • Signs of sepsis (purulent aspirate):
      • Drainage (endoscopic ultrasound-guided is preferred) of the infected fluid. (Statement 5)
      • Antibiotic therapy (Statement 1)
      • Pancreatic necrosectomy (laparotomy). (Statement 6)

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (Statement 4) is not typically used in the management of pancreatic necrosis. It may be used later in the course of the disease to assess the extent of necrosis or complications. CT scan is preferred.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent condition that leads to the occurrence of heartburn and chest pain in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer D) Esophagitis

Explanation:

Esophagitis, characterized by inflammation of the esophagus, presents symptoms such as chest pain, heartburn, acid regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing.

Treatment typically involves Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs).

Barrett's esophagus (Option A) In the lower part or distal oesophagus, the Squamous mucosa is replaced by columnar mucosa, and there is a long history of heartburn.

Pneumonia (Option B) Pneumonia is an infection that affects one or both lungs. The air sacs/alveoli of the lungs are filled up with fluid or pus.

Myocardial infarction (Option C) is caused by decreased supply of blood flow to a portion of the myocardium. Clinical features include chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck, dyspnea, sweating, heartburn, fatigue, and weakness.

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Explanation:

  • On Chest Xray foreign body in the oesophagus is characterized by -
    • On PA view: Flat surface of the coin
    • On Lateral view: Edge of the coin

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) Tracheal foreign bodies are usually seen in the sagittal orientation on AP view due to the airflow pattern. It presents with cough, stridor, or wheezing rather than pure dysphagia.

Foreign body in lungs (Option C) More common in aspiration, affecting the right main bronchus. Symptoms include sudden onset cough, wheezing, respiratory distress, or asymmetric breath sounds. It may show air trapping on expiratory films.

Foreign body in pleura (Option D) Foreign bodies do not typically enter the pleural space unless there is penetrating trauma. Pleural foreign bodies would cause pneumothorax or hemothorax, not dysphagia.
