questions.text: What is the most appropriate next course of action in managing a male patient, aged 40, who presents with widespread abdominal pain and has a confirmed history of Crohn's disease, as well as rigidity and guarding observed during a physical examination, with ileal perforation being detected on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy

Explanation:

Ileal perforation in Crohn’s disease is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate surgical intervention.

Primary repair vs. Ileostomy:

  • Primary repair is not ideal due to inflamed, friable tissue and high recurrence risk.
  • An ileostomy is preferred to divert faecal contents and allow healing before later reversal.

Without surgery, the patient risks septic shock, multi-organ failure, and death.

Antibiotics and NPO (Option A) Supportive care alone is insufficient for a perforation. Antibiotics help control infection but do not treat the perforation. Surgery is mandatory to remove the perforated segment and control peritonitis.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option B) Not useful for small bowel (ileal) disease. Contraindicated in perforation due to risk of further bowel injury.

CT abdomen (Option D) Imaging is already done, confirming perforation. Further delay increases morbidity and mortality. The next step is definitive surgical intervention, not additional imaging.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger. The swelling reaches the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Indirect inguinal hernia

Explanation:

Origin: Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, entering the deep inguinal ring.

Path: Passes through the inguinal canal, sometimes reaching the scrotum.

Complete reduction through deep inguinal ring: Classic for an indirect hernia.

Gurgling sound: Indicates the presence of bowel loops within the hernia sac.

Femoral hernia (Option A) Located below the inguinal ligament, more common in women, and does not extend into the scrotum. No gurgling sound or reducibility through the deep ring.

Direct inguinal hernia (Option B): Bulges through Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Does not extend into the scrotum and is usually more diffuse, not reducible through the deep ring.

Umbilical hernia (Option D) Occurs at the umbilicus, unrelated to the inguinal region.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old patient who has experienced the passage of mucus and blood in their stool, with inflammation predominantly observed in the rectum during sigmoidoscopy, and the presence of crypt abscess detected during biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcerative colitis:

Explanation:

Features

Ulcerative colitis

Crohn’s disease

Location

Limited to colon and rectum

Can involve any part of the GI tract

Distribution

Diffuse lesion

Patchy, with skip lesions.

Gross appearance
  • Mucosal erythema and granularity
  • Broad-based ulcers with a continuous pattern
  • Pseudopolyps
  • Mucosal atrophy
  • Smooth, continuous inflammation
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Cobblestone appearance
  • Fistulae, strictures, abscesses
  • Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping)

Complications
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Colonic dilation
  • Mucosal bridges
  • Strictures
  • Fistulae

Irritable bowel syndrome (Option B) presents with features of abdominal discomfort, bloating, and altered bowel habits (diarrhoea or constipation). No blood in stool, no crypt abscesses, and no inflammation on biopsy.

Crohn's disease (Option C) presents with features of skip lesions, transmural inflammation, and non-caseating granulomas. It can affect any part of the GI tract (mouth to anus), usually sparing the rectum. Fistulas, strictures, cobblestone appearance on endoscopy.

Pseudomembranous colitis (Option D) presents with profuse, watery diarrhoea after recent antibiotic use. Pseudomembranes (yellow plaques) are seen on colonoscopy. No crypt abscesses and inflammation is not limited to the rectum.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position, and the opening is located at the 11 o’clock position, 2 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening, and where does the internal opening start?

choices.text: 12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter
11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter
6 o’clock and crypt of the dentate line

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) 11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter

Explanation:

Goodsall's Rule:

  • Anterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the anterior half of the anus (front side), the fistula usually follows a direct path to the internal opening within the anus.
  • Posterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the posterior half of the anus (back side), the fistula typically follows a curved path, forming a horseshoe shape, and opens internally at the midline of the posterior anus.

The exception to Goodsall's Rule:

  • Anterior external opening more than 3 cm from the Anus: If the external opening is located more than 3 cm away from the anal margin (anterior side), the fistula is likely to track to the posterior midline, rather than following a direct path as Goodsall's Rule would typically suggest.

12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter (Option A): The external sphincter is not the primary site for fistula origin; fistulas originate from the crypts in the dentate line.

11 o’clock, and at internal anal sphincter (Option C), does not follow Goodsall’s Rule; posterior fistulae track to the midline (6 o’clock).

9 o’clock and at the anal verge (Option D): This does not match the typical fistula pattern based on the location given.

questions.text: What is the most probable outcome for the patient after undergoing gastrectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

Gastrectomy (partial or total removal of the stomach) significantly affects nutrient absorption, particularly Vitamin B12, due to the loss of intrinsic factors.

  • Intrinsic factor (IF), produced by gastric parietal cells, is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.
  • Gastrectomy removes parietal cells, leading to intrinsic factor deficiency and causing impaired vitamin B12 absorption.
  • This leads to pernicious anemia, presenting with megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and glossitis.
  • Management: Lifelong B12 supplementation (IM or high-dose oral).

Folic acid deficiency (Option A) Folate is absorbed in the proximal jejunum, which remains intact after gastrectomy. It is not a direct consequence of gastrectomy unless there is associated malnutrition.

Gastric ulcer (Option C) Gastrectomy reduces acid secretion, lowering the risk of gastric ulcers. However, marginal ulcers may develop at anastomotic sites in certain procedures.

Constipation (Option D) Gastrectomy does not directly cause constipation; patients may experience dumping syndrome or diarrhoea instead.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient who exhibits symptoms of dysphagia, experiencing pain behind the breastbone, and regurgitation accompanied by coughing following meals?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Esophageal diverticula

Explanation:

Esophageal diverticula are outpouches or pockets that develop in the wall of the esophagus. These diverticula can interfere with the normal passage of food, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and regurgitation.

Esophageal Diverticula:

Type

Location

Cause

Symptoms

Diagnosis

Treatment

Zenker’s Diverticulum

Upper esophagus (pharyngoesophageal junction)

Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction (pulsion)

Dysphagia, regurgitation, halitosis, aspiration

Barium swallow (posterior outpouching)

Diverticulectomy or endoscopic myotomy

Mid-Esophageal Diverticulum

Mid-esophagus (middle third)

Traction from mediastinal inflammation (e.g., TB)

Usually, asymptomatic or mild dysphagia

Barium swallow (mid-esophageal outpouching)

No treatment unless symptomatic

Epiphrenic Diverticulum

Lower oesophagus (above LES)

Esophageal motility disorders (e.g., achalasia)

Dysphagia, regurgitation, nocturnal cough

Barium swallow (outpouching near LES)

Surgical myotomy or diverticulectomy, if needed

Brown Patterson Kelly syndrome (Option A) presents with iron deficiency anaemia, esophageal webs, and dysphagia. It does not cause regurgitation or retrosternal pain.

Achalasia (Option B) presents with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids. LES fails to relax, leading to the bird’s beak sign on the barium swallow. It does not usually cause significant regurgitation with coughing after meals.

Reflux esophagitis (Option D) presents with heartburn, acid regurgitation, and erosions due to GERD. Dysphagia occurs later due to stricture formation, not an early symptom.

questions.text: In a patient with ascites visiting your clinic for diagnostic paracentesis, you opt for a midline approach to remove the fluid. Which of the following size needles is used during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) 22 gauge

Explanation:

For diagnostic paracentesis, a 22-gauge needle is typically used.

  • Diagnostic paracentesis requires a smaller needle to safely and comfortably extract ascitic fluid for analysis.

  • Larger gauge needles (like 14, 16, or 17 gauge) are more commonly used for therapeutic paracentesis or catheter placement but are not preferred for routine diagnostic fluid sampling due to increased risk of complications and patient discomfort.

Therapeutic vs. Diagnostic Paracentesis

  • It's important to differentiate this from therapeutic paracentesis, which is performed to remove a large volume of ascitic fluid to relieve symptoms such as shortness of breath or abdominal pain.
  • For therapeutic procedures, larger bore needles or catheters (usually 14 to 18 gauge) are often used to facilitate the faster drainage of a larger volume of fluid.

questions.text: A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. A barium swallow was performed, and the following image was shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Diffuse esophageal spasm

Explanation:

  • Diffuse esophageal spasm is a motility disorder of the esophagus. In barium swallow, we can observe a “corkscrew esophagus'' Clinically, chest pain and dysphagia, predominantly while eating spicy food, are the symptoms.
  • Sacculations and pseudo diverticula can also be seen.

 

Infectious esophagitis (Option A) In infectious esophagitis, linear, regular plaque-like lesions can be seen on the contrast X-ray.

Barette’s esophagus (Option C) In Barette's esophagus, the X-ray does not show any specific findings.

Esophageal stricture (Option D) Barium meal shows a narrow esophagus with a shoulder-like appearance

questions.text: The provided barium swallow indicates
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Achalasia cardia

Explanation:

  • Achalasia cardia is a massively dilated esophagus. It has a narrow distal end. Radiologically we can observe a bird beak sign as seen in the given image. A patient suffering from achalasia cardia has more difficulty swallowing liquids than solids.

 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B) A corkscrew sign is seen in the diffuse esophagus.

Nutcracker esophagus (Option C) The nutcracker esophagus also shows a corkscrew sign similar to the diffuse esophageal spasm.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter (Option D) It does not show a bird beak sign, and hence, it is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a barium enema as shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Diverticulosis

  • Diverticulosis is the outpouching of the colon wall. In a barium swallow, the contrast x ray shows an outpouching filled with barium as seen in the image it presents as a “Saw tooth appearance” It is most commonly seen in the sigmoid colon.

 

Multiple colonic polyps (Option A) Colonic polyps appear as single polypoid lesions in the radiograph. It does not present a Sawtooth appearance.

Ulcerative colitis (Option B) A smooth colon with no haustrations “Lead pipe colon” is seen in the radiograph.

Irritable bowel Syndrome (Option D) Saw tooth appearance is not seen in irritable bowel syndrome.

Diverticulosis

Definition

Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Etiology

Diet: A low-fiber diet increases colon pressure.

Age: More common in those over 60.

Genetics: Family history may increase risk.

Pathophysiology

Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge.

Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

Characteristics

False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa.

Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital.

Location: Most commonly in the sigmoid colon, along the mesenteric aspect.

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

 

Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.

CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.

Barium enema: Less common, shows a characteristic sawtooth appearance

Management

Diet: Increase fiber intake.

Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids.

Exercise: Promotes healthy bowel function.

Complications

Lower GI Bleed: Common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in the above condition is FAP ( familial adenomatous polyposis)

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

  • Caused Autosomal dominant mutation in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21.
  • 100% risk of colorectal cancer in those with APC gene mutation.
  • 80% of cases are from positive family history.

Clinical Features:

  • Numerous (>100) colorectal adenomatous polyps, typically develop in adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Rectal bleeding, diarrhoea, abdominal pain
  • Extracolonic manifestations: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), desmoid tumours, upper gastrointestinal polyps, epidermoid cyst (Gardner syndrome)
  • Increased risk of other cancers: duodenal, thyroid, brain (medulloblastoma), hepatoblastoma

Diagnosis:

  • Colonoscopy showing >100 polyps and biopsy showing an adenomatous variety of polyp.

Treatment: The aim of Surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer.

  • Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis.
  • Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)
  • Total proctocolectomy and end-ileostomy.

 

Crohn's disease (Option A) While it can cause rectal bleeding, it doesn't typically present with numerous polyps throughout the colon.

Lynch syndrome/Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) (Option C) This condition increases cancer risk but doesn't usually cause numerous polyps. The average age of onset is later than FAP.

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (Option D) This can cause multiple polyps, but they are typically hamartomatous rather than adenomatous, fewer in number than FAP.

questions.text: During a routine check-up, an elderly male was discovered to have a rectal mass during a digital rectal examination, indicating the possibility of rectal carcinoma. Despite normal bowel habits, the next course of action for managing this patient should be:
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Full colonoscopy and biopsy

Explanation

  • A full colonoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis of rectal carcinoma and to rule out the presence of any synchronous lesions.
  • If any lesions are identified, a biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis and determine the stage and the characteristics of the tumor.

Investigations and Diagnosis of Rectal Carcinoma

  • Digital Rectal Examination:
    • Used to assess the size, consistency (hard), shape (Irregular), and mobility (mobile, tethered, or fixed).
    • A vaginal examination is recommended for women to check for involvement of the posterior vaginal wall.
  • Rigid Sigmoidoscopy:
    • Outpatient procedure for visualising the neoplasm and obtaining biopsies
  • Biopsy and Histological Analysis:
    • Crucial for confirming the diagnosis and distinguishing rectal carcinoma from conditions that may mimic it, such as inflammatory strictures, granulomas, and benign adenomas.
  • Staging Investigations:
    • CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis.
    • Local pelvic imaging with MRI and/or endoluminal ultrasonography provides detailed information about local tumour spread, including infiltration into surrounding tissues and lymph node involvement.
  • Colonoscopy:
    • Essential for most patients to rule out synchronous tumours elsewhere in the colon.
    • Techniques like "dye spray" colonoscopy help differentiate benign from malignant lesions based on mucosal 'pit patterns'.
    • Proximal adenomas can be removed during the procedure; finding synchronous carcinomas may alter surgical strategy.
  • CT Colonography or Barium Enema:
    • Alternatives to colonoscopy if full visualization of the colon is not possible due to stenosing cancer.

 

CT scan of the abdomen (Option A) CT scan of the abdomen is useful in determining the size, location and staging of the tumour.

Rigid sigmoidoscopy and biopsy (Option B) This procedure can only be used to examine the distal portion of the rectum and sigmoid colon but not the entire colon.

Barium enema (Option D) This technique was used earlier but now is vastly replaced by colonoscopy as it is a better diagnostic procedure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with a low-grade fever of 1-week duration associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. Barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Ileocaecal TB

Explanation:

  • In the barium study of the ileum in the case of ileocaecal TB, these are the signs that can be seen in the narrowing of the terminal ileum.
  • Thickening of the ileocecal valve and the thickening of the cecal walls, the cecum appears as a conical shape. In later stages, the ileum is fixed and rigid.

Ileocecal Tuberculosis:

Feature

Details

Definition

A form of abdominal tuberculosis affecting the ileocecal region, the most common site of gastrointestinal TB.

Why the Ileocecal Region?

Rich in lymphoid tissue, slow transit time, and increased uptake of tubercle bacilli.

Common Symptoms

Right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, weight loss, fever, diarrhoea/constipation, and abdominal mass.

Differential Diagnoses

Crohn’s disease, appendicitis, colorectal cancer, lymphoma.

Physical Examination

RLQ tenderness, palpable mass, signs of obstruction (in severe cases).

Imaging Findings

Ultrasound/CT scan: Bowel wall thickening, lymphadenopathy, ascites, strictures.

Endoscopic Findings

Colonoscopy: Ulcers, nodularity, strictures in the ileocecal region.

Histopathology

Caseating granulomas, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Definitive Diagnosis

AFB culture, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Treatment

Anti-TB Therapy (ATT): Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (2 months), followed by Rifampicin + Isoniazid (4 months).

Indications for Surgery

Bowel obstruction, perforation, abscess, stricture, and unresponsiveness to ATT.

Surgical Options

Limited resection (if necessary), stricturoplasty (for non-resectable strictures).

 

Ulcerative colitis (Option B): Radiologically, ulcerative colitis presents with a contracted, pipe-stem colon and thickened, edematous haustra.

Crohn’s disease (Option C): Radiologically, Crohn’s disease is characterised by a cobblestone appearance, making it an incorrect choice.

Carcinoma caecum (Option D) In the case of carcinoma of the cecum, you can see apple core deformity on the right side of the right iliac fossa and not at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with a concern of vomiting blood. He mentions a recent pattern of excessive alcohol consumption. Upon examination, his vital signs are steady, and he has a pale appearance. There are no indications of ongoing bleeding. The results of his liver function tests are within the normal range. To further assess the situation, an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is scheduled. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Mallory-Weiss tear

Explanation:

  • Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal lacerations that occur at the gastroesophageal junction, usually due to severe vomiting or retching.
  • Binge alcohol drinking can lead to forceful vomiting, which may cause these tears. Mallory-Weiss tears are a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding in individuals with a history of alcohol abuse, and they can present with hematemesis.

 

Esophageal varices (Option A) While alcohol abuse can contribute to liver disease, the absence of liver function abnormalities make esophageal varices less likely.

Gastric ulcer (Option B) Risk factors like Helicobacter pylori infection or non-steroidal anti inflammatory drug (NSAID) use is usually more significant in developing gastric ulcers.

Alcoholic gastritis (Option D) Absence of any liver function abnormalities and considering the presentation with hematemesis, Mallory-Weiss tear is a more probable diagnosis compared to alcoholic gastritis.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents Bormann's classification for gastric carcinoma?

choices.text: Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component
Type II: Ulcerated tumor with infiltrative margins
Type III: Diffusely infiltrative tumor with linitis plastica appearance
Type IV: Mucinous carcinoma with extensive peritoneal metastases

questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component:

Explanation:

  • Borrman's classification is a pathologic classification system based on the macroscopic appearance of gastric carcinomas.
  • Type I tumours are characterised by a diffuse polypoidal growth pattern.
  • This combination of a predominantly polypoid growth with a small ulcerated area distinguishes Type I gastric carcinomas according to Borrman's classification.

Bormann’s Classification of Gastric Carcinoma

Bormann Type

Macroscopic Appearance

Key Features

Type I (Polypoid type)

Polypoid or fungating mass

Well-defined borders, grow into the lumen, minimal invasion into the gastric wall, mand ay have a small ulcerated component.

Type II (Ulcerated tumor with distinct borders)

Ulcerated lesion with raised margins

Clearly defined infiltrative edges, but not deeply penetrating into surrounding tissues. (Option B ruled out)

Type III (Ulceroinfiltrative type)

(Option C ruled out)

Deep ulceration with infiltrative margins

Irregular and poorly defined borders, penetrate deeper into the gastric wall, more aggressive than Type II.

Type IV (Diffuse/Infiltrative type – Linitis Plastica)

(Option D ruled out)

Diffuse thickening of the stomach wall

Infiltrative growth without a discrete mass, causes "a leather bottle stomach" appearance, commonly associated with signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vomiting. He reports a 2-day history of constipation and bloating. On examination, he appears uncomfortable, and his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. X-ray reveals dilated loops of the small bowel. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Small bowel obstruction

Explanation:

Small bowel obstruction is the most likely cause in this case. The patient's acute symptoms, abdominal distension, high-pitched bowel sounds, and dilated loops of small bowel on X-ray is consistent with a mechanical obstruction in the small bowel.

 

Colonic malignancy (Option A) Colonic malignancy can lead to obstruction, but it typically causes a gradual onset of symptoms, such as changes in bowel habits, blood in stool, and weight Loss.

Acute pancreatitis (Option C) The presentation of acute pancreatitis often includes epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated serum amylase or lipase levels and may be associated with gallstones or alcohol consumption.

Gastric ulcer (Option D) Gastric ulcers are typically associated with symptoms such as epigastric pain, heartburn, and may be exacerbated by eating.

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

Causes
  • Adhesions (Most common)
  • Malignancy
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • Hernia
  • Crohn's Disease
  • Tb
  • PID
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Cancer

Surgeries with High Risk of Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)
  • Pelvic surgeries (Highest risk)
  • Lower abdominal surgeries
  • Upper abdominal surgeries

Malignancies Responsible for SBO
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis

 

Clinical Features of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Colicky Abdominal Pain (First symptom):
    • Due to hyperperistalsis in the small intestine caused by intestinal obstruction.
  • Multiple Episodes of Bilious Vomiting
  • Obstipation (Absolute Constipation)
  • Proximal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Vomiting
    • Dyselectrolytemia (electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting)
  • Distal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Distension (more prominent)

questions.text: Which of the following findings of colonoscopy is highly malignant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Multiple flat polyp about 100

Explanation:

  • Among the options you provided, the finding of "Multiple flat polyps about 100" is concerning for a higher risk of malignancy. This is because having a large number of flat  polyps (approximately 100) increases the likelihood of some of these polyps being dysplastic or even cancerous.

 

Single pedunculated polyp (Option B) Any polyp has the potential to be cancerous, a single pedunculated polyp, especially if small and without concerning features, is typically considered low risk for malignancy.

Multiple pedunculated polyps (Option C) In the context of multiple pedunculated polyps, further evaluation and genetic testing may be warranted to assess the risk of malignancy.

Solitary flat polyp (Option D) Flat polyps have a higher potential for malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps; the risk still depends on other factors such as size, morphology, and histological characteristics. The malignancy risk of a solitary flat polyp would need to be assessed based on these factors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes McBurney's point in cases of acute appendicitis?

choices.text: McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.
McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis.
McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis.
McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis

Explanation:

  • McBurney point is approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus in the right lower quadrant. It is the site where the appendix is most likely to be inflamed and where maximal tenderness is commonly elicited during physical examination in cases of acute appendicitis.

 

McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen (Option A) McBurney point is not in the left lower quadrant but rather in the right lower quadrant of the Abdomen.

McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis (Option C) Rebound tenderness is assessed by applying pressure at a different location, typically in the left lower quadrant, and observing if there is increased pain when the pressure is released.

McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis (Option D) McBurney point is not located at the umbilicus but rather in the right lower quadrant.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who has been experiencing fever and pain in the lower right abdomen for the past 5 days, with the presence of a tender mass in the right iliac fossa and an elevated leukocyte count?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Appendicitis

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described, including fever, pain in the right lower abdomen, apainful lump in the right iliac fossa, and an increased leukocyte count, the most probable diagnosis would be appendicitis.
  • Appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, a small pouch-like organ located in the lower right abdomen.
  • The classic symptoms include fever, abdominal pain (particularly in the right lower quadrant), and an elevated white blood cell count(leukocytosis).
  • The presence of a painful lump in the right iliac fossa further supportsthe likelihood of appendicitis.

 

Hydronephrosis (Option B) Would present with flank pain, not RLQ pain. No fever or leukocytosis unless there is a secondary infection (pyonephrosis). Ultrasound/CT scan would show dilated renal pelvis and calyces.

Tuberculosis (Ileocecal TB) (Option C) TB presents gradually with weight loss, low-grade fever, and chronic pain, not acute severe RLQ pain. A palpable mass may be present (due to a thickened ileocecal region), but no leukocytosis.

Carcinoma Colon (Right-Sided) (Option D) Presents insidiously with anemia, weight loss, and altered bowel habits. A firm, non-tender mass may be found in the RLQ butis not typically associated with fever or leukocytosis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a female patient who presents with a mass in the inguinal area that can be reduced from the deep inguinal ring accompanied by a gurgling sound?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Indirect inguinal hernia

Explanation:

  • Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type, where abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal. They typically manifest as a palpable mass or bulge in the inguinal area, often reducible with manual manipulation, accompanied by a gurgling sound. More prevalent in males, they can be congenital or acquired later in life.

 

Direct inguinal hernia (Option A) Involves protrusion through a weak point in the abdominal wall without passing through the deep inguinal ring. Common in older men, typically lacking the characteristic gurgling sound upon reduction.

Femoral hernia (Option C) Arises when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, primarily affecting women. Presents as a bulge in the upper thigh or groin area, distinct from the inguinal region, with a narrower passage and typically no gurgling sound upon Reduction.

Pantaloon hernia (Option D) A specific type combining direct and indirect hernias, protruding both above and below the inguinal ligament. Presents with bulges on both sides of the inguinal region and may produce a gurgling sound upon reduction.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Crohn’s disease except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rectum is involved

Explanation:

  • Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus, but it classically spares the rectum. This is a key differentiating feature from ulcerative colitis, which always involves the rectum.

Crohn’s Disease

Feature

Explanation

Transmural involvement

Inflammation extends through the entire thickness of the bowel wall

Serpiginous ulcers

Deep, linear ulcers give a cobblestone appearance to the mucosa

Skip lesions

Areas of normal mucosa interspersed with diseased segments

Recurrence

More common than ulcerative colitis, even after surgery

Rectal sparing

Unlike ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease rarely affects the rectum

 

Serpiginous ulcers (Option B): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease typically forms serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers.

Transmural involvement (Option C): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease affects all layers of the bowel wall.

Recurrence (Option D): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease commonly recurs even after resection.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about colon cancer?

1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently

2. Colon cancers can be hereditary

3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin

4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver
questions.solution:
Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently.

True

Right-sided colon cancer (proximal) is more likely to present with anemia, occult bleeding, and larger polypoid tumors, while left-sided colon cancer (distal) presents with obstruction, hematochezia, and napkin-ring lesions.

2. Colon cancers can be hereditary.

True

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC/Lynch Syndrome) and Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) are genetic syndromes associated with increased colon cancer risk.

3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin.

True

Studies suggest that metformin reduces insulin resistance and suppresses colorectal cancer cell proliferation, lowering the risk, especially in diabetic patients.

4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver.

True

The portal venous system drains the colon to the liver, making it the most common site of metastasis. Other common sites include lungs and peritoneum.

questions.text:
Nonclinical question: Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Hirschsprung’s disease
			
			
			A. MRCP
			
		
		
			
			2. Posterior urethral valve
			
			
			B. CT scan
			
		
		
			
			3. Choledochal cyst
			
			
			C. Rectal biopsy
			
		
		
			
			4. Intussusception
			
			
			D. Micturating cystourethrogram
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

Explanation:

Condition

Investigation

Explanation

Hirschsprung’s disease

Rectal biopsy (C)

Gold standard test to confirm absence of ganglion cells in the colonic submucosa, leading to functional obstruction.

Posterior urethral valve

Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (D)

Identifies posterior urethral obstruction due to congenital valves in male infants, causing urinary retention and hydronephrosis.

Choledochal cyst

MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) (A)

Best non-invasive imaging modality to visualize biliary tree anomalies, including cystic dilatation of the common bile duct.

Intussusception

CT scan (B) (Ultrasound is first-line for children)

CT scan shows the "target sign" in adults, while USG is preferred for children, showing characteristic concentric rings.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are incised by a surgeon during an appendectomy performed initially with a gridiron incision?

1. External oblique

2. Internal oblique

3. Transversus abdominis

4. Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A gridiron incision (also known as McBurney's incision) is a muscle-splitting incision used for an open appendectomy. The incision is made at McBurney's point (one-third of the way from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus).

Layers Incised in a Gridiron Incision:

  1. Skin & Subcutaneous tissue
  2. External oblique aponeurosis → Incised
  3. Internal oblique muscle →Split along its fibers (NOT cut transversely)
  4. Transversus abdominis muscle → Split along its fibers
  5. Transversalis fascia & Peritoneum → Opened to access the appendix

Why Not Rectus Abdominis?

  • Rectus abdominis is NOT involved because the gridiron incision is made in the right lower quadrant, where the rectus abdominis does not extend laterally.
  • If a paramedian or midline incision were used, rectus abdominis would be involved

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is foreign body in the esophagus, as suggested by the X-ray showing an object lodged in the esophagus, causing difficulty swallowing.

Category

Indications

Management

Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects

Immediate endoscopic removal

Urgent

  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours

 

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks

Observation

 

 

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) would cause symptoms like coughing, wheezing, or stridor, but it typically appears as an object in the trachea on X-ray, which is not the case here.

Artifacts (Option C) are typically caused by external factors like motion or poor technique during the X-ray, which would not show a clear foreign body in the esophagus.

Soft tissue calcification in the neck (Option D) refers to calcified structures in the neck, such as lymph nodes or blood vessels, but would not present as a foreign object causing swallowing difficulty.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate management for a patient with a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach involving the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver is Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy.

Treatment of Stomach Cancer

  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for gastric cancer.
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy:
      • Most surgical candidates receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve survival.
      • The FLOT4 trial found that the FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen offers a significant survival advantage over the ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (median overall survival: 50 months vs 35 months).

Types of Gastric Resection

  • Total Gastrectomy:
    • Involves the removal of the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.
    • Includes D2 lymphadenectomy.
    • Preferred for resectable gastric cancer.
  • Subtotal Gastrectomy:
    • It may be performed if the tumour is located in the distal stomach.
    • Involves Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative Surgery:
    • Considered for symptom alleviation in inoperable or metastatic gastric cancer.

Non-Surgical Treatment

  • Palliative Chemotherapy or Radiotherapy: Offered to patients with advanced gastric cancer.

 

Radical gastrectomy (Option B) would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible.

Whipple's procedure (Option C) is used for pancreatic cancer; this procedure is not appropriate here due to gastric cancer with liver metastasis.

Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D) would be considered for resectable localised tumours, but with liver metastasis, it’s not an ideal option for curative intent.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

Explanation:

  • The medial bulge near the inferior epigastric vessels suggests a direct Inguinal Hernia, which protrudes through a weakness in Hesselbach's triangle and is treated with Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • It is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia). (Option C, and D ruled out)

Management of Inguinal Hernia:

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy:
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates.
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh.
  • Herniorrhaphy:
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures
    • Techniques:

Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates. (Option A ruled out)

 

Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

 

 

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair (preferred): Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. (Option A ruled out)

 

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair:
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

 

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair

 

 

TEP

TAPP

Procedure
  • Surgery done above the peritoneum
  • Surgery done beneath the peritoneum

Advantages
  • Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications.
  • Reduced risk of adhesions.
  • Larger working space
  • Better visualisation

Disadvantages
  • Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging.
  • A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

questions.text: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the Procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thiersch wiring

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown is Thiersch wiring, a technique for managing Rectal Prolapse by applying wires or sutures to support the rectal mucosa.
  • It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal

Management of Rectal Prolapse:

Non-Operative Management

  • Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema.
  • Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms.

Operative Management

  • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilization of the rectum.
Aspect
Abdominal Rectopexy
Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

 

Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Option A) aims to remove or reduce prolapsed hemorrhoidal tissue and restore normal anatomical position.

Well's procedure (Option B) is a rare procedure for rectal prolapse, but it involves resection and not the use of wires or sutures (shown above) as in Thiersch wiring.

Altemeier repair (Option D) involves the removal of a segment of the sigmoid colon and rectum through an incision in the perineal area.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is correct?

1. Autosomal dominant disease

2. Defect in the STK11 gene

3. Melanin spots on digits and perianal skin

4. Autosomal recessive

5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome :

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene (statements 1 & 2) (statement 4 ruled out)
  • It presents around 11 years of age.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic but may present with chronic bleeding, anaemia, or intussusception.
  • Histology: An arborising pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.
  • It is characterised by:
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, perianal region and extremities) (statement 3)
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Significant risk of cancers:
    • Small bowel, colon, pancreas, lungs, testis, ovaries, breast, and endometrium
    • Lifetime cancer risk is estimated at 40%

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. On examination, his HR is 110 bpm, BP-88/60 mmHg. Guarding is present on per abdomen examination. Erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with for the management of this case?

A. USG abdomen

B. IV fluids

C. Exploratory laparotomy

D. Elective surgery

E. Conservative management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B & C

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation, along with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) visible on the erect abdominal X-ray, strongly suggests the perforation of a hollow organ.
  • The most appropriate management for this patient, who likely has a gastrointestinal perforation, is to administer IV fluids to stabilise the patient and then proceed with exploratory laparotomy for immediate surgical intervention.
  • Elective surgery is not appropriate for a patient with an acute perforation as it is an emergency, and delaying surgery for an elective procedure would be harmful. (Statement D ruled out)
  • Imaging is already done (X-ray showing free air), so no further imaging (like ultrasound) is required immediately, and conservative management would not be effective or appropriate in this emergency situation. (Statement A & E ruled out)

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas is seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), but it is difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas.
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualisation (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas.
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.
  • Management: is surgical, i.e., Exploratory laparotomy + Peritoneal lavage + Repair of perforation.

questions.text: Identify the following correctly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left inguinal hernia

Explanation:

  • An image of swelling in the left inguinal region is given, which suggests a left inguinal hernia. (Option B ruled out)
  • Inguinal Hernia is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia).

Feature

Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Direct Inguinal Hernia

Common in

Young adults

Elderly

Course

It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring.

Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle

Relation to Spermatic Cord

Anterolateral to the spermatic cord

Posterior to the spermatic cord

Location of Neck of Sac

Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle.

Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels

Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Relation to Scrotum

Descends into the scrotum

Does not Descend

Types
  • Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal
  • Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis
  • Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia

 

 

—

CA bladder (Option A) generally causes symptoms like hematuria, increased frequency, or painful urination, but it would not normally present with bulging in the inguinal area.

questions.text: A man in his middle age arrives with a gradual onset of challenges while swallowing both solid and liquid substances over the course of 8 months. The results of a barium swallow test conducted are provided below. What additional examinations should be conducted for this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

Explanation:

  • Given that the barium swallow findings are suggestive of achalasia, the appropriate next steps are to perform an upper GI endoscopy to rule out any other structural causes and oesophagal manometry to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.

 

Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan (Option B): PET scan is used to detect malignancy or assess metastasis. In the case of achalasia, PET scans are not indicated because this is a benign motility disorder.

Upper GI endoscopy & CECT (Option C): CECT is helpful for evaluating masses, inflammation, or complications (e.g., abscess, perforation), but it would not provide any additional information on oesophagal motility, which is the primary concern in this case.

Upper GI endoscopy & 24-hour pH monitoring (Option D): 24-hour pH monitoring is used primarily for diagnosing GERD, not achalasia.

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following can be seen in this child?

A. Bilious vomiting

B. Visible peristalsis from left to right

C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia

D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B, C and D

Explanation:

  • Visible peristalsis from left to right, hypochloremia and hypokalemia, and Metabolic alkalosis are seen in a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 - 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age. (Statement A ruled out)
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Tillaux sign?

choices.text: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
Mass is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line

Explanation:

  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery accurately describes the Tillaux sign which is a component of Tillaux’s triad.
  • Tillaux’s triad is associated with mesenteric cysts.

Mesenteric cysts

Definition
  • It presents as a painless abdominal swelling in the umbilical region.
  • Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life.
  • There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst.

Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts
  • A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out)
  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign)
  • A zone of resonance all around.

Complications
  • Torsion of cysts can lead to volvulus of the adjacent bowel.
  • Rupture of the cyst.
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst.
  • Infection

 

Mass is brilliantly transilluminate (Option B): Transillumination refers to shining light through a cyst or mass and observing whether the light passes through, indicating it is filled with fluid or air. However, Tillaux’s sign is about the movement of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery.

Fluctuation is positive (Option D): Fluctuation is a clinical sign used to detect fluid-filled masses noted in cases like hydatid cysts or cystic lesions. However, fluctuation is not specific to the Tillaux sign, which does not focus on detecting fluid content within the mass.

questions.text: Which of the options accurately represents a valid statement concerning retroperitoneal trauma?

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury, whether blunt or penetrative, should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

Explanation:

  • Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically, is the correct statement.
  • In Zone 2, expanding hematoma confined to the lateral retroperitoneum without active bleeding and hemodynamically stable patient angioembolisation is a suitable option to prevent or control bleeding while avoiding the risks associated with open surgery.
  • Angioembolization is a minimally invasive procedure that involves the selective occlusion of bleeding vessels.
  • The retroperitoneum is divided into three zones for intraoperative management in blunt trauma:

 

Zone I – Central

  • Associated with injuries of
    • The aorta & its proximal branches
    • Inferior vena cava & its proximal tributaries
  • Management: Central hematoma - exploration with proximal & distal vascular control (Option A ruled out).

 

Zone 2 - Lateral

  • Structures located - Distal renal vessels
  • Management:
    • Lateral hematoma (renal in origin) - managed nonoperatively (angioembolisation) (Option C)
    • Pulsatile hematoma or penetrating injury present - exploration.

Zone 3 - Pelvic

  • Confined to the retroperitoneal zone of the pelvis
  • Structures located - Iliac vessels
  • Management: Pelvic hematoma is exceptionally difficult to control. Usually, it should not be opened. It is managed by packing/angioembolisation. Explored only if there is expanding or pulsatile, or penetrating injury present. (Option B ruled out)

Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilised to the right to visualise the Aorta (Option D). This is incorrect because the Mattox maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries, it involves mobilising the left colon (not the ascending colon) to gain better access to the aorta and other retroperitoneal structures for surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

Explanation:

  • The mesh that is most appropriate for use during hernioplasty is Lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • The choice of mesh is important as it affects the outcome of the procedure and the long-term success of the hernia repair.
  • Lightweight:
    • It provides sufficient strength and support while minimising the risk of complications like mesh-related pain and discomfort. The reduced material leads to less inflammation and tissue reaction, which improves patient comfort and recovery. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Large pores:
    • Large-pore meshes allow better tissue integration, enabling the mesh to become well-incorporated into the patient’s tissue. This improves healing and reduces complications like infection or seroma formation. The flexibility of large-pore meshes also helps with the natural movement of the abdominal wall, which is essential for long-term functionality. (Options A & C ruled out)

questions.text: According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Umbilical

Explanation:

  • According to the European Hernia Society (EHS) classification, M3 refers to an incisional hernia located in the umbilical region.
  • The classification divides incisional hernias into two main categories: Midline & Lateral.

EHS Classification of Incisional Hernia

 

 

 

 

Midline

Subxiphoid

M1

Epigastric

(Option A ruledout)

M2

Umbilical

M3

Infraumbilical

(Option B ruledout)

M4

Suprapubic

(Option D ruledout)

M5

 

 

 

Lateral

Subcostal

L1

Flank

L2

Iliac

L3

Lumbar

L4

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, which type of achalasia does the patient have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Type III

  • The given description in the question, massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions, corresponds to Type III achalasia and is defined by spastic contractions of the oesophagus.

Chicago Classification of Esophageal Motility (4.0)

Esophageal Disorder

Description

Values

1. Achalasia

Type I

Minimal contractility (Option B ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis

Type II

Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option A ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurisation

Type III

Spastic contractions (Option D)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO)

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis

3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s)

4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus

Extremely strong peristaltic contractions

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM)

Weak or failed peristalsis

Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis)

6. Absent Contractility

Complete lack of esophageal contractility

Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis

Type IV (Option C) is not part of the classification mentioned above.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a middle-aged man who comes to the emergency department with upper abdominal pain following a large meal? During clinical examination, there is tenderness in the upper abdomen, and a chest X-ray reveals a widening of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

  • The given presentation, along with the findings on chest X-ray, is suggestive of esophageal perforation, particularly a spontaneous perforation (also known as Boerhaave syndrome).
  • It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation.
  • The rupture leads the gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Classic triad: Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema).
  • Symptoms: May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis.
  • Physical exam: Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema).
  • Complications: Pneumothorax, mediastinitis, and sepsis.

Perforation of peptic ulcer (Option B) can cause localised abdominal pain and even air under the diaphragm, but not pneumomediastinum.

Foreign body in esophagus (Option C) presents with dysphagia, odynophagia, and discomfort. The clinical signs and pneumomediastinum on the X-ray are more suggestive of perforation or rupture rather than foreign body ingestion.

Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung (Option D) generally presents with respiratory symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or cough, particularly in patients with COPD. The lack of these symptoms makes it less likely than oesophagal perforation.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered neuroendocrine tumour in the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Insulinoma

  • Insulinoma is the most common type of neuroendocrine tumour found in the pancreas, which is usually benign and results in excessive insulin secretion, causing hypoglycemia.

Insulinoma

Category

Details

Definition

A rare, typically benign tumour of the pancreatic islet cells that produce excess insulin.

Clinical Features

Whipple's Triad:

  • Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes
  • Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose
  • Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise

Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures)

Diagnosis
  • Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast.
  • Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia
  • Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic
  • Imaging:
    • CT, MRI, EUS

Management
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
  • Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumours.

Gastrinoma (Option A) is a neuroendocrine tumour that arises from the cells producing gastrin in the pancreas. While they are commonly associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which involves excessive gastrin production and gastric acid hypersecretion, they are less common than insulinomas.

Somatostatinoma (Option B) is a somatostatin-secreting tumour usually found in the pancreas or duodenum and is rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome.

VIPoma (Option D) is a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). They cause Verner-Morrison syndrome, characterised by watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. VIPomas are much less common than insulinomas.

questions.text: What stage of Hinchey's classification is indicated when a patient with clinical features suggestive of peritonitis presents with diverticular perforation and faecal peritonitis during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Stage 4

  • The presence of faecal peritonitis indicates that faecal material has spilled into the peritoneal cavity, which is a hallmark of Stage 4 in the Hinchey classification.
  • The Hinchey classification is used to stage the severity of diverticulitis and its associated complications.

Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis)

Stage 0

Mild diverticulitis

Stage 1

(Option A ruled out)

Ia: Pericolic inflammation

Ib: Pericolic abscess

Stage 2

(Option B ruled out)

Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess

Stage 3

(Option C ruled out)

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: In MEN 1 syndrome, where is the most frequent occurrence of gastrinoma observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Duodenum

  • In MEN 1 syndrome, the most frequent occurrence of gastrinomas is in the duodenum.
  • Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete gastrin, a hormone that stimulates acid production in the stomach. This leads to conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • These tumours are mainly found in the small intestine or pancreas, with the duodenum being the most common extrapancreatic site for gastrinomas. (Other options ruled out)
  • While surgical resection is indicated in some cases, it is not curative in all. Surgical resection can be curative only if metastasis is absent.
  • Treatment involves proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression, high-dose PPI therapy for acid control, and somatostatin analogues as adjunctive therapy

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pharyngeal pouch

Explanation:

  • The given barium swallow film shows a characteristic radiological finding known as a Pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum.
  • It is an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa through a weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall (Killian's dehiscence).

Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis(Chronic bad breathe)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:

 
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

Aortic aneurysm (Option A) is a dilatation or bulge in the aorta, which is the main artery that carries blood from the heart. It is visualised via CT scan or angiography but not barium swallow.

Carotid body tumour (Option C) is a rare, slow-growing tumour that arises from the carotid body, which is located near the carotid bifurcation. They are better diagnosed using CT or MRI but not by using a barium swallow.

Esophageal carcinoma (Option D) presents with narrowing or strictures in the oesophagus due to tumour growth. Whereas a pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum) is a protrusion from the pharynx

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a gradual onset of swallowing difficulties for both solid and liquid foods, persisting for 8 months. The barium swallow test results are presented below. The patient undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux
<75% relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
It is a primary motility disorder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux

Explanation:

  • The given condition, along with the barium swallow finding, is suggestive of Achalasia cardia, which is characterised by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax.
  • Achalasia is associated with increased pressure rather than a loss of pressure of the LES.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is a primary motility disorder (Option B ruled out) characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

(Option A & D ruled out)

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris. It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

questions.text: What would be the subsequent course of action for managing a 35-year-old woman who has been experiencing swelling in her right groin for the past six months, as determined during her arrival at the emergency department? Upon examination, a reducible hernia is observed in the right groin without any signs of strangulation.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and later observe
Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery

Explanation:

  • For a reducible hernia with no signs of strangulation, the correct course of action is to reduce the swelling and proceed with elective surgery.
  • A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall.
  • They are at a higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.
  • Hence, elective surgery is advised to repair the hernia and prevent complications.

 

Exploratory laparotomy (Option A) is an invasive procedure that is usually performed when there is concern about internal injury, peritonitis, or significant abdominal pathology. In this case, since the hernia is reducible and there are no signs of strangulation, a laparotomy is not needed.

Reduce the swelling and later observe (Option B) is not ideal as a surgical intervention should still be planned in the near future to prevent any complications like recurrent or incarcerated hernias.

A CT abdomen (Option D) is not necessary here because the diagnosis of a reducible hernia is already done, and there are no signs of strangulation. It may be required if there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or if other abdominal pathologies are suspected.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis for a newborn infant presenting with signs of intestinal obstruction, as indicated by the x-ray image and CT abdomen showing an annular pancreas, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Duodenal atresia

Explanation:

  • The given x-ray shows a classic finding of Duodenal atresia, which is the "double bubble" sign, where there are two air-filled spaces visible: one in the stomach and one in the duodenum, indicating obstruction at the level of the duodenum.

Duodenal Atresia

Pathophysiology
  • Failed recanalisation of intestinal lumen during gestation

Associated Conditions
  • Prematurity (50%)
  • Congenital anomalies (heart disease, malrotation, annular pancreas, etc.)
  • Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21)

Clinical Presentation
  • Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention.
  • Symptoms typically present within the first few days of life.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed by the double bubble sign on the abdominal X-ray and prenatal ultrasonography.

Treatment
  • Initial: Nasogastric decompression and IV fluids
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (Duodenoduodenostomy)
  • Postoperative care: Gastrostomy tube, nutritional support

Jejunoileal atresia (Option A) is characterised by multiple dilated loops of the small bowel and a "triple bubble sign" on X-ray, not the double bubble sign. It can cause bilious vomiting, and polyhydramnios association is less common compared to duodenal atresia.

Esophageal atresia (Option B) involves a discontinuity or abnormality of the esophagus, often presenting with excessive drooling, coughing, difficulty feeding, and respiratory distress. Imaging shows a gas-filled or gasless abdomen and a coiled tube in the upper oesophagus.

Colonic atresia (Option D) refers to a blockage or absence of a portion of the colon, which is less common than other forms of atresia. It would not present with the classic "double bubble" sign in duodenal atresia or annular pancreas.

questions.text: A patient who underwent Nissen’s fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present and has stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome
Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Monitor vitals

Explanation:

  • Given that the patient is asymptomatic and has stable vitals, the primary management at this stage is to continue monitoring their vitals closely.
  • Nissen fundoplication is a surgical procedure used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD); it involves wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to increase the pressure at the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES), reducing reflux.

Management of GERD

Lifestyle Changes
  • Elevate the head of the bed
  • Avoid lying down after meals
  • Quit smoking

Medical management
  • Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid
  • H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole

Surgical management

Antireflux operation: 3 components

  • Restoration of the intra-abdominal segment of the esophagus
  • Crural repair
  • Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis.

Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to strengthen the sphincter.

  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen)
  • Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate.
  • Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients.
  • Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower oesophagal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

 

 

Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome (Option A): While gas bloat syndrome can be a complication post-surgery, it would not necessitate routine nasogastric tube insertion unless symptoms of bloating or distension arise.

Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax (Option B): There is no indication of a pneumothorax, and the patient is asymptomatic with stable vitals, making a chest tube unnecessary.

Imaging to rule out perforation (Option D) is not recommended as the patient is asymptomatic and stable, without signs of perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following do not require instruments to examine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute anal fissure

Explanation:

  • An acute anal fissure is a fresh, superficial tear in the anal canal lining typically caused by trauma, such as passing a large stool. It can be diagnosed through a visual inspection and digital rectal examination without the need for any specialised instruments like anoscopes or proctoscopes.

 

Carcinoma rectum (Option B) requires a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy to visualise and assess the tumour's extent. Imaging studies are also needed to evaluate staging.

Haemorrhoids (Option C): While external haemorrhoids can be diagnosed through visual inspection, internal haemorrhoids typically require the use of an anoscope or proctoscope for proper assessment.

Rectal polyps (Option D) are usually diagnosed and removed using colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy, making instruments necessary for both diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Identify the incision marked as B
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lanz incision

Explanation:

  • B in the given image depicts Lanz incision which is a type of incision used commonly in appendectomy surgery. It is a low transverse incision made in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Types of Incisions used for appendicectomy

Name of the incision

Incision area

Type of incision

McBurney's incision

(A in the image)
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision (Option A ruled out)
