Lanz incision

(B in the image)

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision (Option D ruled out) / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision

(C in the image)

(Option C ruled out)

 
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis.
  • Upward & laterally by cutting the conjoint tendon.
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carcinoid tumours in the appendix is false?

choices.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behaviour and metastatic potential
Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Leiberkuhn
Most common location is the base of the appendix
Most common tumor of the appendix

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Most common location is the base of the appendix

Explanation:

  • The most common location of carcinoid tumours in the appendix is actually the tip of the appendix, not the base.

Carcinoid tumor of the appendix (aka Argentaffinoma)

Definition

(Options A & D ruled out)
  • They are neuroendocrine tumours that originate from the enterochromaffin cells (also known as Kulchitsky cells) of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They are considered the most common tumours of the appendix.

MC Location

Tip of the appendix

Clinical Presentation

Mostly discovered incidentally during surgery

Larger tumours may cause abdominal pain, flushing, and diarrhoea due to hormone secretion

Hormone Secretion

Secretes serotonin and other vasoactive substances.

Risk of Metastasis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Low for tumours <2 cm
  • Higher for tumours>2 cm

Diagnosis

Confirmed by histopathological examination

Treatment
  • <2 cm: Appendectomy
  • >2 cm: Right hemicolectomy

questions.text: The most common type of gastric sarcoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GIST

Explanation:

  • GISTs are the most common type of gastric sarcoma and arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which are involved in the regulation of gastric motility.
  • These tumours are often located in the stomach and can be malignant.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)

Mutations
  • Most common- c-KIT/CD117
  • Others:
    • PDGFR- beta
    • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- Small baby( Pediatric GIST)

Mechanism

KIT (c-kit) is a proto-oncogene encoding a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations result in constant activation of KIT signalling, driving tumour growth and survival.

Common Locations
  • Stomach: 60-70% of cases.
  • Small Intestine: 20-30%.
  • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).

Treatment
  • Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors - Imatinib
  • Surgical management

 

Liposarcoma (Option B) is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that originates from adipose (fat) tissue. While liposarcomas can occur in the stomach, they are less common compared to GIST.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant smooth muscle tumour. Although they can occur in the gastrointestinal tract, they are less common than GISTs in the stomach.

Epithelioid sarcoma (Option D) is a rare and aggressive sarcoma that affects the soft tissues (primarily arise in the deep tissues) of the limbs or other peripheral areas; they can also happen anywhere in the body.

questions.text:
What structures are contained within the anterior pararenal space?


	Head, neck, and body of the pancreas
	Adrenal gland, kidney, ureters
	Aorta, inferior vena cava
	Ascending and descending colon
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,4

Explanation:

  • Anterior pararenal space lies between the posterior parietal peritoneum & the perirenal fat, and it contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).
  • The retroperitoneum divides into three main anatomical spaces:

Retroperitoneal spaces

Anterior pararenal space

It contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), the ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).

Perirenal space

This includes the adrenal gland, kidney, ureters, and renal vessels. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Posterior pararenal space

It is surrounded by the posterior leaf of the renal fascia and muscles of the posterior abdominal wall, contains no major organs and is composed primarily of fat, blood vessels, and lymphatics.

There is also a fourth, less well-defined space known as the great vessel space. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and psoas muscles and contains the aorta, inferior vena cava, and surrounding fat. (Statement 3 ruled out)

questions.text: What electrolyte imbalance is commonly observed in patients with this postoperative condition, as depicted in the provided x-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypokalemia

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a typical appearance of a paralytic ileus.
  • It is a common postoperative condition where the normal peristalsis of the intestines is temporarily reduced or absent, leading to a buildup of gas and fluid in the intestines, often seen on X-ray, which is frequently associated with hypokalemia.

Paralytic ileus

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g. hypokalemia) (Option B)
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

 

IOC: Abdominal X-ray.

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

 

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing faeces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

Hypocalcemia (Option A) can cause muscle cramps and other symptoms, but it is not typically associated with paralytic ileus.

Hyperkalemia (Option C) does not commonly result in paralytic ileus.

Hypercalcemia (Option D) is not associated with paralytic ileus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a past history of peptic ulcer disease. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urgent surgical exploration

Explanation:

  • The presence of air under the diaphragm on an X-ray (pneumoperitoneum) is a classic sign of perforated viscus, most commonly due to a perforated peptic ulcer which is a surgical emergency.
  • Physical examination findings of rigidity and past history of peptic ulcer disease also support this diagnosis.
  • Hence, the most appropriate next step in management is urgent surgical exploration to repair the perforation and address any potential complications, such as peritonitis.
  • Delaying the surgery can lead to potential complications.

 

Antibiotics and NPO (nothing by mouth) (Option A) are part of the supportive treatment; they are not sufficient alone in this case. The presence of free air under the diaphragm indicates a perforation that requires immediate surgical intervention.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option B) is useful for identifying ulcers in the non-perforated stage, but this patient already shows signs of perforation, including rigidity and free air; hence, surgery is the immediate priority.

CT abdomen (Option D) of the abdomen can provide valuable information in many cases of abdominal pain, including suspected perforation, but it is not the next best step when there are signs of peritonitis, such as rigidity during physical examination.

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

Explanation:

  • The neonate's presentation of mild intermittent upper abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, and decreased breath sounds on both sides, along with X-ray findings showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, strongly points toward a Bochdalek hernia.
  • It is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.

Bochdalek hernia

Aspect

Description

It is due to the failure of the fusion of the pleuroperitoneal canal, which leads to direct communication between the pleura and peritoneum on the left side.

Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory embarrassment
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

Pneumonia (Option B), while being a common cause of respiratory distress, would not typically present with bowel loops in the thoracic cavity on X-ray. It usually shows lung consolidation, infiltrates, or pleural effusion on imaging, not abdominal organs in the chest.

Gastric volvulus (Option C) involves twisting of the stomach, which can lead to obstruction, pain, and vomiting, but it does not cause bowel loops in the thoracic cavity.

Eventration of the diaphragm (Option D) is a condition where there is diaphragmatic weakness or paralysis, leading to the upward displacement of abdominal contents into the chest. While it may cause respiratory distress, it does not lead to bowel loops in the chest on X-ray.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a neonate who is brought to the hospital with complaints of forceful vomiting that is not accompanied by bile after feeding? The child appears lethargic and dehydrated, and abdominal examination shows visible movements of the stomach. A barium meal was conducted, and the image provided is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Explanation:

  • The neonate presenting with the mentioned complaints and the barium swallow showing a “string sign” suggests Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS).

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age.
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic ¸ with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

 

 

Hirschsprung’s disease (Option A) is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal intestine, which can present as delayed passing of meconium or constipation. Barium enema shows the dilated proximal segment and the transition zone. Forceful vomiting without bile and visible stomach movements are not typical of Hirschsprung's disease.

Jejunal atresia (Option C) is a condition where there is a congenital obstruction in the jejunum, often presenting with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. It is characterised by multiple dilated loops of the small bowel and a "triple bubble sign" on X-ray. In this case, the vomiting is non-bilious, which rules out this diagnosis.

Duodenal atresia (Option D) is another congenital condition where there is a complete or partial obstruction of the duodenum, which results in bilious vomiting. It often presents with a "double bubble" sign on the X-ray.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child with abdominal swelling, mild discomfort, no pain or vomiting, and a fluctuant soft swelling that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, as seen in the outpatient department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chylolymphatic cyst

Explanation:

  • The description of the abdominal swelling, which is fluctuant, soft, and moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, strongly points toward a Chylolymphatic cyst.
  • It is a type of mesenteric cyst, which is a rare, benign cystic lesion that typically contains chyle (lymph fluid mixed with fat). These cysts are often seen in children and are related to lymphatic malformations. (Congenitally misplaced lymphatics)
  • Pathophysiology: absence of efferent lymphatics → collection of chyle→ progressive increase in the size of the cyst.
  • The cyst is usually soft, fluctuant, and non-tender, aligning with the clinical presentation.
  • The cyst moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, which is characteristic of cysts within the mesentery or mesenteric root.

Peritoneal cysts (Option A) are also fluid-filled sacs within the peritoneal cavity, but they tend to be less common in children and often do not exhibit the same characteristic free movement seen in chylolymphatic cysts.

Lipoma (Option B) is a benign fatty tumour, typically firm and mobile but not fluctuating in consistency. They are solid masses and do not show the fluctuating and soft characteristics described here. They also typically don't show distinct movement in relation to mesenteric attachment.

Pseudocysts (Option D) are more commonly associated with acute or chronic pancreatitis and would typically present with symptoms such as abdominal pain or other signs of pancreatic pathology.

questions.text: The image below shows an image of the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and it occurs when one of your anus glands becomes clogged and infected? Pus and fluid accumulate in the anal gland, resulting in an excruciatingly painful abscess around your anus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perianal abscess

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this scenario, based on the symptoms described and the given clinical image, is a perianal abscess.
  • It is an infection of one of the small glands near the anus, known as anal glands or crypts. These glands can become blocked or infected, leading to pus accumulation, resulting in an abscess.
  • It is a type of anorectal abscess that occurs in the perianal region.
  • It can also develop as a complication of Crohn's disease.
  • Treatment of perianal abscess:
    • Surgical Drainage: It is the primary treatment, often performed under anaesthesia. The abscesses are drained via perineal skin using a cruciate incision, avoiding excessive excision of healthy tissue.
    • Antibiotics: Indicated in cases with extensive cellulitis, diabetes, or immunosuppression.

Hemorrhoids (Option A) are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus. While they can cause pain, discomfort, and sometimes bleeding, haemorrhoids do not result in pus accumulation or an infected abscess.

Pelvirectal abscess (Option B) develops when the intersphincteric abscess extends cranially past the levator muscles. The infection progresses semicircularly and primarily posteriorly, resulting in the creation of a horseshoe abscess or fistula. Such a condition does not represent the case here.

Pilonidal sinus (Option D) are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair. However, this condition is not located around the anus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old male patient who visited the surgery OPD with a history of occasional discharge of pus with a slight presence of blood from an external opening in the perianal region, despite multiple attempts at drainage? The examination of the perianal region is depicted below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fistula-in-ano

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient, with an occasional discharge of pus with slight blood from an external opening in the perianal region, despite multiple drainage attempts, along with the findings of the clinical image given, is Fistula-in-Ano.
  • It is a chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Fistula-in-ano

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Parks classification

Type 1 - Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2 - Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3 - Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4 - Extra- sphincteric (1%)

 

Pilonidal sinus (Option A) is found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair. It occurs higher up near the coccyx, not in the perianal region.

Perianal abscess (Option B) is an infection of one of the small glands near the anus, known as anal glands or crypts. These glands can become blocked or infected, leading to pus accumulation and abscess. This patient has had multiple drainage attempts and ongoing discharge, suggesting a chronic issue. Hence, he likely has a chronic fistula rather than an acute abscess.

Hemorrhoids (Option C) are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus. While they can cause pain, discomfort, and sometimes bleeding, pus discharge is not characteristic of hemorrhoids.

questions.text: An infant of 12 weeks presented with the following defect in the umbilical area. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Umbilical hernia

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this 12-week-old infant with a defect in the umbilical area is Umbilical Hernia.
  • It is a protrusion of abdominal contents (usually fat or intestines) through a weakness in the abdominal wall at the umbilical ring. This condition is more common in infants and obese adults.
  • In infants, it is a benign condition, often noticed shortly after birth, and the hernia usually appears as a soft swelling in the umbilical area that may disappear when the infant is lying down or when pressure is applied.
  • It mostly resolves spontaneously in infants before 2 years, without needing any intervention.
  • If they have not resolved by 2 years of age, surgical repair is considered.

Omphalocele (Option A) is a condition where, instead of the abdominal wall completely closing, some of the internal organs protrude out of the body through the umbilical area. These organs are not just exposed to the environment but are enclosed in a protective membrane (peritoneum, Wharton’s jelly & amnion). They are usually much larger than hernia, and the given clinical condition aligns more with an umbilical hernia.

Gastroschisis (Option B) is the evisceration of bowel contents through a defect in the anterior abdominal wall just lateral to the umbilicus. It is characterised by a defect beside the umbilicus and does not present in the same way as an umbilical hernia.

Paraumbilical hernia (Option D) is a protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall, but it occurs slightly above or below the umbilicus rather than directly at the umbilical ring. The swelling is located directly at the umbilicus in the infant, which is more characteristic of an umbilical hernia rather than a paraumbilical hernia.

questions.text: A patient, after heavy drinking of alcohol presents with multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Explanation:

  • Given the patient's history of heavy drinking, multiple episodes of vomiting, and hematemesis, the most likely diagnosis is Mallory-Weiss syndrome, where the vomiting-induced tear leads to bleeding from the oesophagus.

Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Definition

It is defined as mucosal lacerations in the gastric mucosa at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction that are caused by forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.

Epidemiology
  • It accounts for 10-15% of acute upper gastrointestinal haemorrhages.
  • The greatest risk for massive haemorrhage is alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension.

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholic patients with intense vomiting after binge drinking.
  • Forceful abdominal contractions against a closed cardia.
  • Any patient with repeated episodes of emesis.
  • Portal hypertension in alcoholic patients.

Diagnosis
  • The patient's history is crucial.
  • It can be confirmed with endoscopy.
  • Retroflexion manoeuvre during endoscopy is used to view the area below the gastroesophageal junction.

Symptoms

Vomiting, hematemesis, upper abdominal pain, hypotension, tachycardia

Complications

Rarely massive bleeding associated with portal hypertension

Treatment

Endoscopic methods (multipolar electrocoagulation, epinephrine injection, band ligation), angiographic transarterial embolisation, rarely surgery

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate endoscopic treatment

Esophageal carcinoma (Option B) can present with dysphagia, weight loss, and anorexia. It may cause hematemesis in advanced stages, but it is less likely to be associated with acute episodes of vomiting or retching, as seen in this patient.

Achalasia cardia (Option C) is a disorder of the lower esophageal sphincter, causing difficulty in swallowing and regurgitation of food, but it doesn't usually present with hematemesis or the tears caused by vomiting.

Boerhaave's syndrome (Option D) involves a rupture of the oesophagus due to severe vomiting or retching. It presents with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, pleural effusions, tachypnea, fever, and hypotension. It is a life-threatening condition often associated with violent vomiting, much more severe than Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for inguinal hernia in infants is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Herniotomy

Explanation:

  • The treatment of choice for inguinal hernia in infants is herniotomy, which involves the removal of the hernial sac.
  • This procedure is preferred in infants as it effectively addresses the condition by removing the sac and preventing further complications, such as incarceration or strangulation, without the need for complex repair techniques used in older patients.

Herniorrhaphy (Option B) is a more complex procedure involving suturing the defect in the abdominal wall, which is more commonly used in older children and adults but not typically in infants due to the smaller size and risks associated with suturing in such delicate tissues.

TRUSS (Option C) is a device used to support a hernia, but it is not a definitive treatment. It does not address the anatomical defect; hence, it is not preferred for managing inguinal hernias and is not recommended for infants.

Hernioplasty (Option D) is a procedure that typically involves the use of a mesh to repair a hernia defect. It is usually employed in adults or in complex, large, or recurrent hernias. In infants and younger children, herniotomy is the preferred treatment. Hernioplasty is considered in specific, complex cases but is not the routine treatment for inguinal hernias in infants.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Crohn’s disease except
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rectum is involved:

  • Rectum is involved more commonly in UC while it is spared in CD. The inflammatory nature of disease ensure it has waxing and waning course with flare ups/ recurrences. CD leads to full thickness involvement of entire GIT. The damage occurs in form of deep serpiginous ulcers that break through the serosal side and lead to fistula formation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Rest of the options are characteristics of UC.

questions.text: Gall stone chemistry most commonly seen amongst the following is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate:

  • Gallstones can be composed of various substances, but the most common type of gallstone seen is made up of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.
  • Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate stones are yellowish in color and make up approximately 80% of all gallstones.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: Cholesterol dihydrate stones are less common and often coexist with cholesterol monohydrate stones.

Option C - Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate is a non-crystalline form of cholesterol that does not commonly contribute to the formation of gallstones.

Option D - Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate is another non-crystalline form of cholesterol that is not typically associated with the formation of gallstones.

questions.text: During an emergency laparotomy performed for a patient with intestinal obstruction, which organ would you initially observe to determine whether it is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Caecum: The caecum is the first part of the large intestine, situated in the lower right abdomen. It receives the contents from the ileum and is involved in the absorption of water and electrolytes. Visualizing the caecum during an emergency laparotomy can help determine if the obstruction is in the large bowel.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Ileum: The ileum is the final part of the small intestine, located between the jejunum and the large intestine (cecum). It is responsible for the absorption of nutrients. In cases of small bowel obstruction, the ileum can become dilated and distended.

Option C. Jejunum: The jejunum is the middle part of the small intestine, located between the duodenum and the ileum. It plays a crucial role in nutrient absorption. In cases of small bowel obstruction, the jejunum can also become distended.

Option D. Sigmoid colon: The sigmoid colon is the S-shaped portion of the large intestine that connects the descending colon to the rectum. It is the final part of the colon before the rectum. Sigmoid colon obstruction typically presents as a distinct entity and is not commonly confused with small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of abdominal pain that started around the umbilicus and has now localised to the right lower quadrant. He also reports nausea and loss of appetite. On examination, he has tenderness in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness. His temperature is 38.2°C. Laboratory investigations reveal a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm3 with a left shift. What is his pain score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10

Explanation:

  • The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used to help diagnose acute appendicitis.
  • The score is based on symptoms, signs, and laboratory results, with a score of 7 or more being strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.
  • A score of 5 is equivocal, suggesting additional investigation with USG or CECT for the confirmation of the diagnosis of acute appendicitis.

MANTREL

Score

Migratory pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea, Vomiting

1

Tenderness

2

Rebound tenderness

1

Elevated Temperature

1

Leukocytosis

2

Shift to Left

1
  • Score of 9-10: Diagnosis is certain
  • Score of 7-8: High likelihood of diagnosis
  • Score of 5-6: Equivocal (most dangerous)
    • CECT is indicated in cases of Equivocal MANTREL score findings to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Score of 1-4: Negative for acute appendicitis
  • According to the given situations

MANTREL

Pesent/Absent

Score

Migratory pain

Present

1

Anorexia

Present

1

Nausea, Vomiting

Present

1

Tenderness

Present

2

Rebound tenderness

Present

1

Elevated Temperature

Present

1

Leukocytosis

Present

2

Shift to Left

Present

1

Hence, total MANTRELS score = 1 + 1 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 + 1 = 10

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoes colonoscopy for evaluation oc altered bowel habits. A 6cm colonic mass is identified and biopsied. Histopathology confirms adenocarcinoma that is confined to the mucosal layer, with no evidence of invasion into the submucosa or beyond. Imaging studies show no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. Based on this information, what is the most appropriate TNM stage of this tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage 0

Explanation:

  • ​​This patient's colon cancer is confined to the mucosal layer (also known as carcinoma in situ) and does not invade the submucosa. According to the TNM (Tumor, Node, Metastasis) staging system, it is Stage 0.

TNM classification of colon cancer

T (Tumor)

Tis

Carcinoma in situ/tumor confined to mucosa

T1

Tumor invades the submucosa

T2

Tumor invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor invades through subserosa or into pericolorectal tissues

T4a

Tumors breaches visceral peritoneum

T4b

Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures.

N (Lymph Node)

N1a

Metastasis in 1 regional lymph node.

N1b

Metastasis in 2-3 regional lymph nodes.

N1c

Tumor deposits in the subserosa, mesentery, or non-peritonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues without regional nodal metastasis.

N2a

Metastasis in 4-6 regional lymph nodes.

N2b

Metastasis in 7 or more regional lymph nodes.

M (Metastasis)

M1a

Metastasis confined to one organ or site

M1b

Metastasis to more than one organ/site or the peritoneum.

M1c

Metastasis to the peritoneum with or without other organ involvement.

 

Stage 0: Tis N0 M0

Stage 1: T1/T2 N0 M0 (Option A)

Stage IIA: T3 N0 M0 (Option B)

Stage IIB: T4a N0 M0 (Option C)

Stage IIC: T4a N0 M0

Stage IIIA: T1/T2 N1/N1c M0 or T3/T4 N2a M0

Stage IIIB: T3/T4a N1/N1c M0 or T2/T3 N2a M0 or T1-T2 N2b M0

Stage IIIC: T4a N2a M or T3/T4a N2b M0 or T4b N1/N2 M0

Stage IVA: anyT anyN M1a

Stage IVB: anyT anyN M1b

Stage IVC: anyT anyN M1c

questions.text: Identify the procedure done?

choices.text: Single Anastamosis Duodenal-Ileal Bypass with Gastrectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Single Anastamosis Duodenal-Ileal Bypass with Gastrectomy

Explanation:

  • The image is a Single Anastomosis Duodenal-Ileal Bypass with Gastrectomy.
  • It is a is a bariatric surgery combining:
    • Sleeve gastrectomy &
    • Single anastomosis of the duodenum (just distal to the pylorus) directly to the ileum.
  • Indications for bariatric surgery:

 

International Population

Asian Population (metabolic surgery)
  • BMI ≥ 40kg/m2 with/without comorbidities (Option A)
  • BMI ≥ 35kg/m2 with comorbidities (Option B)
  • BMI ≥ 37.5kg/m2 with/without comorbidities (Option D)
  • BMI ≥ 32.5kg/m2 with comorbidities

 

Gastric bypass (Option B) also Roux-en-Y involves the creation of a small gastric pouch from the proximal end of the stomach, which is then connected with the distal jejunum. It is different from the single anastomosis in SADI-S

 

Sleeve Gastrectomy (Option C) involves resection of a large part of the stomach, which regulates appetite, creating a tube-like structure. It does not require gastrointestinal anastomosis or intestinal bypass.


Adjustable gastric banding (Option D) is a purely restrictive bariatric procedure that creates a small proximal gastric pouch by placing an adjustable band around the stomach just below the cardia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a history of diarrhea associated with blood in stool for several weeks. On examination, the patient is febrile and has abdominal distension and tenderness. A CT scan (coronal view) shows a grossly dilated colon with loss of haustrations. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcerative colitis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and CT findings are suggestive of Toxic megacolon, which is a severe complication most commonly associated with Ulcerative colitis.
  • It is a potentially life-threatening condition characterised by rapid dilation of the colon, systemic toxicity, and risk of perforation.
  • Ulcerative colitis is a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) that presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and rectal bleeding as it primarily affects the colon and almost always involves the rectum with broad areas of ulceration.
  • Skip lesions, bowel wall thickening, and perianal manifestations like fissures and granulomas are uncommon in Ulcerative colitis.

Complications of Ulcerative Colitis

Complications of Crohn’s disease

(Option B)
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Intestinal perforation
  • Anaemia
  • Colonic malignancy (UC is a premalignant condition)
  • Perianal fistula
  • Abscess
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Strictures
  • Intestinal obstruction

Colonic carcinoma (Option C) usually presents with weight loss, anaemia, and change in bowel habits, but not commonly with acute febrile illness or diffuse colonic dilatation.

﻿﻿﻿Intestinal tuberculosis (Option D) commonly affects the ileocecal region, presents with chronic symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and sometimes obstruction, but not normally with toxic megacolon.

questions.text: Which of the following are correctly paired:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Achalasia - Los Angeles Score

Explanation:

  • Achalasia is staged using the Eckardt score (symptom-based) or Chicago classification (manometry-based).
  • The Los Angeles (LA) classification is used for Reflux esophagitis, not achalasia.

  • The ANNHEIM classification (Option A) is used to assess severity in acute pancreatitis (based on organ failure and pancreatic necrosis).
  • The Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) (Option C) assesses colonoscopy cleanliness.
  • The Miami criteria (Option D) guide intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) monitoring in primary hyperparathyroidism surgery. A drop in the PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents with a scrotal swelling that has been present since birth. Now, the swelling has become suddenly painful, red, and irreducible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strangulated inguinal hernia

Explanation: The infant has a congenital scrotal swelling (likely due to a hernia present since birth) that has become painful, red, and irreducible, suggesting that bowel has entered the hernial sac and is now compromised with vascular obstruction - this is the definition of a strangulated inguinal hernia.

  • This is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent bowel necrosis.

Strangulated Hernia:

  • A strangulated hernia occurs when a portion of tissue or intestine protrudes through a weakened area in the abdominal wall and becomes trapped.
  • The trapped segment loses its blood supply, leading to tissue ischemia (lack of blood flow) and potential tissue death if not promptly treated.

Clinical Features:

  • Irreducibility: The hernia cannot be pushed back.
  • Signs of Intestinal Obstruction: Colicky pain, bilious vomiting, absence of faeces and flatus.
  • History: Sudden onset of pain at the hernia site, followed by generalised abdominal pain.
  • Physical Examination Findings: Tense, extremely tender hernia with reddish or bluish skin discolouration and no cough impulse.
  • Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical examination and physical findings.

Treatment:

  • Initial Resuscitation:
    • Administer intravenous (IV) fluids.
    • Provide IV antibiotics.
    • Perform nasogastric aspiration.
    • Insert Foley's catheter.
  • Surgical intervention is done only after Initial Resuscitation.

Surgical management Algorithm:

Mesh Usage:

  • Synthetic mesh is contraindicated due to the increased risk of infection.
  • If a mesh is necessary, bioprosthetic or absorbable mesh is preferred.

Acute epididymo-orchitis (Option A): Presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema but is rare in this age group and usually associated with urinary tract infection; swelling is not from birth.

Testicular torsion (Option B): Sudden severe scrotal pain and swelling, but not present since birth; does not involve an irreducible groin/scrotal mass.

Incarcerated inguinal hernia (Option D): Irreducible hernia without compromised blood supply; no redness or severe tenderness — if blood supply is compromised, it becomes strangulated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for esophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endoscopic ligation

Explanation:

  • Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is the first-line treatment for acute bleeding esophageal varices and for secondary prophylaxis. It works by mechanically strangulating varices, leading to thrombosis and obliteration, with fewer complications than sclerotherapy.

Management of Esophageal varices:

  • The immediate priority in managing variceal bleeding is stabilizing the patient's condition. This involves the airway, breathing, and circulation.
  • Establishing intravenous access with large-bore cannulae allows for rapid fluid resuscitation, ideally with blood transfusions, to restore circulatory volume and address hypotension.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (Option B): Used as a salvage therapy when bleeding persists or recurs despite optimal endoscopic and pharmacologic management.

Intravenous labetalol (Option C): Not used; nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol or nadolol are used for prophylaxis, not labetalol.

Oral amoxicillin (Option D): Antibiotics (usually ceftriaxone) are given prophylactically in variceal bleeding, but amoxicillin is not the standard choice and does not control bleeding.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for an 8cm chylolymphatic mesenteric cyst?

choices.text: Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Enucleation

Explanation:

  • Chylolymphatic mesenteric cysts are typically benign, well-encapsulated lesions arising from lymphatic malformations in the mesentery. The majority are attached to the mesentery but do not infiltrate the bowel wall, meaning the cyst can be separated from the mesenteric vessels without compromising bowel blood supply.
  • Preferred treatment: Complete enucleation of the cyst while preserving the bowel, to prevent recurrence and avoid unnecessary resection.

Tillaux Triad:

  1. Peri-umbilical swelling
  2. Tillaux sign → swelling moves at right angle to mesentery
  3. Transverse band of resonance

Investigation of choice: Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT)

Types of Mesenteric Cysts

 

Chylolymphatic cyst (most common)

Enterogenous cyst

Origin

Sequestered lymphatic tissue

Sequestered bowel tissue

Wall

Thin

Thick

Fluid

Clear

Turbid

Blood supply

Independent

Shares with bowel

Treatment

Enucleation

Resection + anastomosis

Site distribution:

  • Small intestine → 60%
  • Colon → 40%

Complications:

  • Torsion
  • Rupture
  • Infection
  • Hemorrhage

Aspiration (Option A) – Not definitive; high recurrence/infection risk.

Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel (Option C) – Needed only when the cyst shares vascular supply with the bowel or infiltrates the wall.

Conservative (Option D) – Not appropriate due to risk of enlargement, infection, torsion, or rupture.

questions.text: A follow-up patient of GERD on endoscopy was having a nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum, which hormone are you suspecting to be raised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Gastrin

Explanation:

  • A nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum in a patient with GERD symptoms raises suspicion of a gastrinoma (Zollinger–Ellison syndrome).

Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor → marked acid hypersecretion → severe peptic ulcer disease.
  • Common sites:
    • Duodenum (~70%)
    • Pancreas (~25%)
    • Other sites (~5%) — stomach, lymph nodes.
  • Gastrinoma Triangle:
    • Cystic duct–CBD junction
    • Junction of 2nd & 3rd part of duodenum
    • Neck & body of the pancreas.

  • Associations: MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1) → Gastrinoma + Pituitary adenoma + Parathyroid hyperplasia.
  • Clinical features:
    • Refractory peptic ulcers (often multiple, distal to duodenal bulb)
    • GERD
    • Chronic diarrhea (acid inactivates pancreatic enzymes → malabsorption)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Fasting serum gastrin >1000 pg/mL (very high suspicion)
    • Secretin stimulation test → paradoxical rise in gastrin.
    • Imaging: Endoscopic ultrasound, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.
  • Treatment:
    • High-dose proton pump inhibitors (acid suppression).
    • Surgical excision if localized.

Inulin (Option B) – Not a hormone; used as a marker for GFR measurement.

VIP (Option C) – Elevated in VIPoma; causes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome), and no duodenal nodules with GERD.

Glucagon (Option D) – Elevated in glucagonoma; presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, and anemia, typically in the pancreas, not the duodenum.

questions.text: A neonate has intestines protruding from the abdomen without any external covering. What will be your next line of management?

choices.text: Cover the content with a Silo bag and wait

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Cover the content with a Silo bag and wait

Explanation:

  • A neonate with intestines protruding without any external covering is most likely gastroschisis. In gastroschisis, the bowel is directly exposed to air and amniotic fluid postnatally, making it edematous, thick, and friable. If the abdominal cavity is too small to accommodate the swollen bowel without causing respiratory compromise, primary surgical closure is avoided initially. Instead, the bowel is placed in a sterile silo bag to protect it, prevent fluid loss, and allow gradual reduction of contents into the abdomen over several days, after which definitive closure is performed. This staged approach minimizes the risk of abdominal compartment syndrome and preserves bowel viability.
  • Another gastric defect is an Omphalocele.

Gastroschisis vs Omphalocele:

Feature

Gastroschisis

Omphalocele

Defect location

Right of umbilicus

Through umbilicus

Covering

None (bare bowel)

Peritoneum + amnion sac

Associated anomalies

Rare (~10%)

Common (~60%, esp. cardiac, chromosomal)

Cause

Vascular disruption of the right omphalomesenteric artery

Failure of midgut return & closure

Bowel appearance

Thick, edematous, and inflamed

Normal, within sac

Initial management

Silo bag, staged reduction

Protect sac, repair when stable

Image

Surgical correction (Option A) – Primary closure may cause abdominal compartment syndrome; not preferred if bowel is edematous or the abdominal cavity is small.

Conservative management with higher antibiotics (Option B) – Inadequate; needs urgent protective intervention for bowel.

Cover with NS soaked gauze (Option D) – Temporary measure if silo unavailable, but definitive staged reduction in silo is standard.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple episodes of abdominal pain and a history of passing blood in his stools. On examination, he has darkly pigmented spots on his lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Based on the above signs and symptoms, this classic triad is diagnostic of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (PJS), a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by STK11/LKB1 gene mutation. There is an increased risk for multiple cancers: GI (colon, stomach, pancreas), breast, ovary, cervix, and testes.

Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome (PJS):

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Gene: STK11/LKB1 tumor suppressor gene mutation (chromosome 19p13.3).
  • Pathology: Multiple hamartomatous polyps (non-neoplastic, but with malignant potential due to genetic instability).
  • Features:
    • Mucocutaneous pigmentation → dark spots on lips, buccal mucosa, fingertips.
      • Pigmentation is due to melanin deposition in the basal cell layer (resembles freckles, but in the mucosa too).

    • Hamartomatous polyps predominantly in the small intestine (especially jejunum).
    • Symptoms: abdominal pain, GI bleeding, intussusception (due to large polyps).
  • Complications:
    • Intussusception (the most common acute presentation in children)
    • GI bleeding → anemia
    • Malignancy risk: GI tract (esp. pancreas), breast, gonadal tumors
  • Management:
    • Symptomatic relief for obstruction/bleeding
    • Endoscopic polypectomy for large polyps
    • Cancer surveillance: colonoscopy, upper GI endoscopy, pancreatic screening

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (Option A) – Hundreds to thousands of adenomatous (not hamartomatous) polyps in the colon, due to APC gene mutation; no mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (Option C) – Multiple juvenile polyps (hamartomas) in colon/rectum, usually <5 years; no mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Cronkhite–Canada Syndrome (Option D) – Non-hereditary, middle-aged adults; GI polyps + alopecia, skin hyperpigmentation, nail atrophy (but not perioral mucosal pigmentation pattern).

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the child.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Umbilical Hernia

Explanation:

  • The image shows a soft swelling at the umbilicus in a child, which is characteristic of an Umbilical Hernia.

Definition: Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring due to incomplete closure of the abdominal wall after birth.

Typical presentation in children:

  • Soft bulge at the navel.
  • More prominent when the child cries, coughs, or strains.
  • Usually painless.

Etiology: Common in infants, especially premature babies, due to delayed closure of the umbilical ring.

Prognosis: Most close spontaneously by 2–3 years of age.

Spigelian Hernia (Option B): Occurs along the semilunar line (lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle), not at the umbilicus.

Inguinal Hernia (Option C): Presents as swelling in the groin or scrotum, not at the umbilicus. It is commonly due to a patent processus vaginalis.

Femoral Hernia (Option D): Appears as swelling below the inguinal ligament, more common in adult females.

questions.text: Which of the following veins are involved in the formation of esophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Left gastric vein

Explanation:

  • Esophageal varices occur due to portal hypertension (commonly from liver cirrhosis).
  • In portal hypertension, blood flow is obstructed in the portal vein, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses.

One important site is lower esophagus, where:

  • Portal circulation: Left gastric vein (drains into portal vein)
  • Systemic circulation: Esophageal veins (drain into azygos vein → superior vena cava)

Increased pressure in the left gastric vein causes dilated submucosal esophageal veins → varices.

Right gastric vein (Option B): Drains the lesser curvature of the stomach. It connects to the portal vein, but not a major contributor to lower esophageal varices.

Left gastroepiploic vein (Option C): Drains the greater curvature of the stomach into the splenic vein (portal system). It is not involved in esophageal portosystemic anastomosis.

Right gastroepiploic vein (Option D): Drains into the superior mesenteric vein (portal system). It has no role in esophageal varices.

questions.text: Identify the fistula according to park’s classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intersphincteric

Explanation: The given image depicts Intersphincteric fistula.

Parks classification:

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: What type of hernia is a funicular hernia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Indirect inguinal hernia:

  • The funicular is a type of indirect inguinal hernia.
  • An indirect inguinal hernia occurs as a failure of the processus vaginalis to close.
  • It passes lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Direct inguinal hernia:

  • Direct inguinal hernia occurs due to a defect in the transversalis fascia.

Option C - Femoral hernia:

  • It protrudes below the inguinal ligament, lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Option D - Umbilical hernia:

  • An umbilical hernia can occur when fatty tissue or a part of the bowel protrudes into an area near the umbilicus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intersphincteric:

  • Based on Park's classification, the most common type of anal fistula is intersphincteric.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trans-sphincteric: Trans-sphincteric is the second most common type of anal fistula.

Option C - Suprasphincteric: They can be iatrogenic.

Option D - Extrasphincteric: They usually result from pelvic disease or trauma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had acute appendicitis 3 days ago and presented to the surgery department with abdominal pain and tenderness. Which of the following incisions would be appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3:

  • The appropriate incision for acute appendicitis is McBurney's incision.
  • It is in right lower quadrant of the abdomen, approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the umbilicus. The incision is usually 4-5 cm long and is oriented obliquely with the upper end towards the ASIS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1: Kocher's incision is a subcoastal incision to gain access for gall bladder and biliary tree pathology.

Option B - 2: Midline incision -This type of incision is typically used for surgeries involving multiple organs or structures, such as bowel resections

Option D - 5: Lanz incision -It is typically used for surgeries involving the descending colon and rectum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. An endoscopy was performed, an image of which is given below; what is the probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mallory Weiss Tear:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking who presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood is Mallory Weiss Tear.
  • Mallory Weiss Tear is a condition characterized by a tear between the esophagus and the stomach, known as the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It is commonly associated with alcoholism and binge drinking, as well as with excessive vomiting and retching.

Incorrect Options: 

Correct Option A - Tension pneumothorax: It typically presents with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia and is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.

Option B - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome, also known as Spontaneous Esophageal Perforation, typically occurs due to forceful or repeated vomiting, predominantly affecting males.

Option D - Gastric ulcer perforation: Gastric ulcer perforation is when an ulcer in the stomach lining erodes through the stomach wall, leading to a hole or perforation.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of massive, sudden onset hematemesis in a 50-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease and chronic alcoholism, who has arrived at the emergency department?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bleeding esophageal varices:

  • The most likely cause of massive, sudden onset hematemesis in a 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with a history of chronic liver disease is bleeding esophageal varices.
  • As the portal hypertension worsens, pressure in the veins surrounding the liver increases, leading to the formation of collaterals or new blood vessels. These collaterals are fragile and can rupture easily, leading to massive bleeding.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Mallory Weiss tear: Mallory Weiss tear refers to a tear in the mucous membrane at the junction of the esophagus and stomach, often caused by forceful vomiting or retching.

Option C - Boer-haave’s syndrome: Boer-haave’s syndrome refers to a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus, typically caused by forceful vomiting or retching.

Option D - Perforated ulcer: Perforated ulcer refers to a hole in the wall of the stomach or duodenum, typically caused by an ulcer.

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate presents abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Among the following, which is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CECT abdomen:

  • The most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition in a 3-day-old neonate with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting is a CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography) abdomen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C - Barium swallow, Barium meal & Barium meal follow through:

  • Ingestion of a significant amount of barium, which can be harmful to a newborn's delicate digestive system.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given radiograph of a newborn.:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imperforate anus:

  • The given radiograph of a newborn indicates the presence of an imperforate anus.
  • The radiograph shows the absence of a normal gas pattern in the rectum and sigmoid colon, which is indicative of an obstruction. This is further supported by the presence of a distended abdomen, which is a common symptom of an imperforate anus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meningocele: This condition is not visible on a radiograph of the abdomen.

Option C - Congenital megacolon: This condition can cause abdominal distension, but it does not involve the anus and would not show an absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

Option D - Pyloric stenosis: This condition can cause vomiting and dehydration, but it would not affect the anus and would not cause the absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation to establish a diagnosis of GERD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 24 hours ambulatory pH monitoring:

  • 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring is the best investigation to establish a diagnosis of GERD.
  • It involves the insertion of a small probe through the nose into the esophagus to monitor acid levels in the esophagus over a 24-hour period.
  • This test can help to identify episodes of acid reflux and assess the severity of the condition.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Upper GI endoscopy: It can help to identify esophageal inflammation, ulcers, or other structural abnormalities that may be contributing to symptoms, but it may not always detect the presence of acid reflux.

Option C & D: CECT & MRI are of no use in GERD.

questions.text: A 42-year-old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Peptic ulcer perforation:

  • The likely cause of the patient's symptoms and findings on the bedside radiological imaging is Peptic ulcer perforation.
  • Bedside radiological imaging may show the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, a classic finding in patients with a perforated peptic ulcer.
  • The patient's fever and tachycardia may be due to the systemic inflammatory response caused by peritonitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tension pneumothorax: Tension pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing compression of the lung and mediastinal shift. 

Option C - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome is a rare but life-threatening condition characterized by a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus, usually because of prolonged vomiting. 

Option D - Mallory Weiss tear: Mallory Weiss tear is a condition in which there is a tear in the mucosa at the junction of the esophagus and stomach, usually caused by excessive vomiting or retching.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common deficiency observed after gastric bypass /bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Iron:

  • Iron is the most common mineral deficiency seen after gastric bypass surgery. The stomach produces hydrochloric acid, which helps to break down food and release iron from it. After gastric bypass surgery, the amount of stomach acid produced is reduced, leading to decreased iron absorption. This can result in iron deficiency anemia, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Copper: Copper deficiency is also relatively common after bariatric surgery, particularly in people who have undergone malabsorptive procedures, but it is not the most common one..

Option C - Zinc: Zinc deficiency can occur after bariatric surgery, especially in people who have undergone malabsorptive procedures. Symptoms of zinc deficiency include hair loss, skin lesions, and impaired immune function.

Option D - Calcium: Calcium deficiency is less common than iron, copper, or zinc deficiency after bariatric surgery, but it can still occur.

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to 

1. Hypoglycemia 

2. Small volume of food intake 

3. High osmotic load of food 

4. Increased release of insulin 

5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1 and 4:

  • Response, causing a drop in blood glucose levels, resulting in symptoms such as dizziness, fatigue, and tremors.
  • (1) Hypoglycemia & (4) Increased release of insulin
    • Increased insulin release due to the rapid influx of glucose into the small intestine, leading to hypoglycemia.
    • This excessive insulin release exacerbates the drop in blood glucose levels, contributing to the symptoms experienced by the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D: Refer to the explanation of the correct option.

Incorrect Statements

  • (2) Small volume of food intake: Dumping syndrome is characterized by the rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, after consuming a regular or large meal.
  • (3) High osmotic load of food is incorrect because dumping syndrome does involve hyperosmolar contents being rapidly emptied into the jejunum.
  • (5) Increased release of glucagon is incorrect because dumping syndrome leads to an increased release of insulin, not glucagon.

questions.text: A young adult with gastric outlet obstruction presents with vomiting. Which of the following fluids is preferred in this patient for initial resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Normal saline:

  • Normal saline is an isotonic solution that is similar in composition to extracellular fluid. It is the preferred fluid in this condition as it helps to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance, does not affect gastric pH, and does not stimulate gastric secretions. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ringer lactate:  it contains lactate, which can increase gastric acid production and worsen vomiting.

Option C - 5% dextrose in water: 5% dextrose in water are hypertonic solution that can worsen fluid overload and hyponatremia in patients with gastric outlet obstruction. 

Option D - 20% dextrose in water: 20% dextrose in water are hypertonic solution that can worsen fluid overload and hyponatremia in patients with gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 34 years old female with a history of alcohol intake was taking NSAIDs for abdominal pain. She developed severe pain in the whole abdomen. A radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hollow viscus perforation:

  • The radiograph in question shows air under the diaphragm, which indicates pneumoperitoneum. This finding is consistent with the diagnosis of "hollow viscus perforation."
  • There is a tear in gastrointestinal organs like the stomach or intestines, causing leakage of digestive fluids and waste into the abdomen, leading to inflammation and potential infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rupture of ectopic pregnancy: Rupture of an ectopic pregnancy can cause internal bleeding and abdominal pain, but it typically does not cause pneumoperitoneum, as seen in the radiograph.

Option B - Acute pancreatitis: it does not usually cause pneumoperitoneum, as seen in the radiograph.

Option C - Perforated liver abscess:it typically does not cause pneumoperitoneum, as seen in the radiograph.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a patient who had a bronchospasm history, and was found to have a tumor in their ileum along with elevated levels of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid in their urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Carcinoid tumor:

  • One of the hallmark features of carcinoid tumors is the secretion of serotonin, which can lead to elevated levels of urinary 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA). This is because serotonin is converted to 5-HIAA in the liver and then excreted in the urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Neuroblastoma: It is most commonly diagnosed in infants and young children and can cause symptoms such as abdominal swelling or pain, fever, and weight loss. 

Option C - Leiomyoma: Leiomyoma is a benign tumor arising from smooth muscle tissue and can occur in various parts of the body (including the uterus, gastrointestinal tract, and skin). 

Option D - Chromaffinoma: Chromaffinomas can cause symptoms such as high blood pressure, palpitations, sweating, and headache but do not typically secrete serotonin or cause elevated 5-HIAA levels (although they can secrete other hormones such as adrenaline and noradrenaline)

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will you first visualize to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Caecum:

  • The caecum is the first part of the large intestine or colon.
  • During a laparotomy, when examining the caecum:
    • If the caecum is distended, it indicates the obstruction is beyond the caecum.
    • If the caecum is collapsed, it suggests the patient is experiencing small bowel obstruction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Platelet transfusion:

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically done as a primary intervention for active variceal bleeding. Platelets are not directly involved in the clotting mechanism of variceal bleeding, which is primarily caused by increased portal pressure and vascular wall abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Arrange pRBC: It aims to correct anemia and maintain hemodynamic stability by restoring blood volume and oxygen-carrying capacity.

Option C - IV Octreotide: It is a synthetic somatostatin analog that reduces splanchnic blood flow and inhibits the release of various vasoactive substances, including vasodilatory peptides.

Option D - Urgent Endoscopy: It allows for direct visualization of the bleeding site, identification of high-risk stigmata, and the application of endoscopic therapies, such as band ligation or sclerotherapy, to achieve hemostasis.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 28-year-old patient who is an alcoholic and presents to the hospital with symptoms of frequent vomiting, chest pain, fever, and hydropneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Boerrhave syndrome:

  • In the given scenario of a 28-year-old alcoholic patient presenting with binge vomiting, chest pain, fever, and hydropneumothorax, the probable diagnosis is Boerrhave syndrome.
  • Boerrhave Syndrome also known as spontaneous esophageal rupture, is a rare but life-threatening condition characterized by a full-thickness tear or rupture of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tension Pneumothorax: it is not directly related to the binge vomiting and hydropneumothorax in this scenario.

Option C - PUD Perforation: it is not directly associated with the symptoms of binge vomiting, chest pain, and hydropneumothorax described in the scenario.

Option D - Mallory Weiss Tear: it can cause upper gastrointestinal bleeding, it is not typically associated with chest pain, fever, or hydropneumothorax.

questions.text: What could be the possible cause of sweating and diarrhea occurring within 20 minutes of eating in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Early Dumping syndrome:

  • Dumping syndrome is a condition that can occur after gastrectomy, a surgical procedure where a part or the entire stomach is removed.
  • It is characterized by a rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to various symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Late dumbing syndrome: Late dumping syndrome occurs 1 to 3 hours after a meal and is characterized by symptoms like weakness, lightheadedness, sweating, and palpitations due to reactive hypoglycemia.

Option C - Hyperglycemia: it can cause symptoms such as increased thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue, it is not typically associated with sweating and diarrhea after eating.

Option D -Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia may occur as a result of excessive insulin release during the early dumping syndrome, but the predominant symptoms in this case are sweating and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 6 months child presented with the following presentation. What is the management protocol?

choices.text: Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Surgery after 5 year:

  • In the given clinical scenario a 6-month-old child presents with an image suggestive of umbilical hernia.
  • Umbilical hernias in infants often resolve on their own without any intervention by the age of 2 years but persistence beyond 5 years is an indication of surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years:

  • Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years is not right as surgery is indicated after 5 yr age

Option C -Immediate surgery:

  • Immediate surgery, is incorrect for uncomplicated umbilical hernias in infants.

Option D - Hernioplasty:

  • Hernioplasty is a surgical technique used to repair hernias.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for Esophageal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oxalate food:

  • While oxalate-rich foods can contribute to the formation of kidney stones in some individuals, they are not directly linked to the development of esophageal cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease): Chronic reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus can lead to chronic inflammation, cellular damage, and an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

Option B - Betel chewing: Betel nuts contain carcinogenic substances, and the habit of chewing betel nuts is prevalent in certain regions, especially in South Asia.

Option D - Spicy food: The relationship between spicy food and esophageal carcinoma is not well-established.

questions.text: Alvarado score of 2 is given for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tenderness in right lower quadrant:

  • The Alvarado score is a scoring system used in the assessment of suspected acute appendicitis.

  • It takes into account various clinical signs, symptoms, and laboratory findings to help evaluate the likelihood of appendicitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nausea: Only 1 point is given for nausea.

Option B - Temperature: The Alvarado score assigns 1 point for a elevated temperature.

Option D - Migratory pain: Only 1 point is given for Migratory pain

questions.text: 20 year old female previously diagnosed with Adenocarcinoma of the stomach, on examination following image was seen. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sister mary joseph nodule:

  • The given clinical image in a patient with adenocarcinoma stomach shows Sister Mary Joseph nodes.
  • The presence of cutaneous metastatic deposits around the umbilicus is referred to as Sister Mary Joseph nodes, which are not lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Virchow's node: Virchow's node, also known as left supraclavicular lymph node enlargement, is often associated with metastatic cancer, particularly from the gastrointestinal tract or pelvic region. it is not specifically associated with the umbilicus, as seen in the image provided.

Option B - Irish node:It is thought to arise from intrathoracic metastatic spread of an intra-abdominal malignancy, particularly gastric cancer

Option D - Infected umbilical hernia: An infected hernia would typically present with signs of inflammation, such as redness, warmth, and tenderness, rather than a discrete nodule.

questions.text: Where is the location of Killian's dehiscence, which causes Zenker's diverticulum, in a 40-year-old male presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation, and a foul-smelling mouth, and diagnosed after further evaluation in the emergency department?

choices.text: Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Between inferior constrictor:

  • Killian's dehiscence is the anatomical defect or weakness in the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • In Zenker's diverticulum, the herniation of the esophagus occurs through this specific area, which is located between the inferior constrictor muscles cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Above superior constrictor: Killian's dehiscence is not located above the superior constrictor muscle.

Option C - Below the cricopharyngeal muscle: Killian's dehiscence is not located below the cricopharyngeal muscle.

Option D - Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus: Killian's dehiscence is not located below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome except:

choices.text: Arise from beta cell tumors of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Arise from beta cell tumors of the pancreas:

  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is associated with gastrinomas, which are neuroendocrine tumors derived from the cells that produce gastrin. Gastrinomas can occur in various locations, including the pancreas, duodenum, and other areas of the gastrointestinal tract.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Intractable peptic ulcers: These ulcers are persistent and do not heal despite conventional treatment. They are usually located in the upper part of the duodenum but can also occur in the stomach and other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

Option B - Severe diarrhea: It is caused by the excessive production of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates gastric acid secretion.

Option D - Very high acid output: Gastrinomas in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome produce excessive amounts of gastrin, leading to the hypersecretion of gastric acid. This high acid output contributes to the development of intractable peptic ulcers and other symptoms associated with the condition.

questions.text: Most common type of intussusception:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ileocolic: 

  • Ileocolic intussusception is the most common type of intussusception. It involves the invagination of the ileum (small intestine) into the colon (large intestine). This type of intussusception accounts for the majority of cases, particularly in children.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are the less common types.

questions.text: Serum acid phosphate is raised in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Prostatic carcinoma:

  • Prostatic carcinoma, or prostate cancer, is a malignant tumor that develops in the prostate gland. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the commonly used marker for prostate cancer, but serum acid phosphate levels can also be elevated in some cases.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma can lead to elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, it is not typically associated with raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

Option C - Paget's disease: Paget's disease can cause elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, it is not typically associated with raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

Option D - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism can affect phosphate levels, it does not typically cause raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

questions.text: Dohlman's procedure is for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Dohlman's procedure, also known as pharyngoesophageal myotomy, is a surgical approach used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. It involves making a small incision or myotomy in the muscular wall between the esophagus and the diverticulum. This allows for the release of the pressure and improves the emptying of the diverticulum, relieving the associated symptoms.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the small intestine.

Option C - Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia is a type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Option D - Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease is a rare stomach disorder characterized by enlarged gastric folds and excessive mucus production.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma:

  • Rectal carcinoma is predominantly composed of adenocarcinoma, which is the most common histological type of rectal cancer. Adenocarcinoma arises from the glandular cells lining the inner surface of the rectum. Therefore, adenocarcinoma is not a rare variant of rectal carcinoma; it is the most common type.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are correct.

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute pancreatitis:

  • In the context of the given options, acute pancreatitis is the condition associated with a gasless abdomen. In severe cases of acute pancreatitis, the inflammation and associated fluid collections can lead to a loss of normal gas patterns in the abdomen, resulting in a gasless appearance on imaging.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are not the correct answer.

questions.text: What does the presence of serpiginous ulcers during esophageal endoscopy in a patient indicate in terms of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - CMV esophagitis:

  • When esophageal endoscopy reveals the presence of serpiginous ulcers, it is indicative of CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis.
  • The characteristic finding of serpiginous ulcers refers to the appearance of shallow, linear ulcers that follow a winding or serpentine pattern in the lining of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Candida esophagitis: It may present with white patches or plaques but not serpiginous ulcers.

Option C - Herpetic esophagitis: It can lead to small, shallow ulcers, but they are not typically described as serpiginous.

Option D - Radiation esophagitis: It can present with mucosal changes, ulcers, or strictures, but serpiginous ulcers are not a typical feature.

questions.text: What is the name of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gastrinoma triangle:

  • The gastrinoma triangle is defined as the confluence of the cystic and common bile duct superiorly, the second and third portions of the duodenum inferiorly, and the neck and body of the pancreas medially, both dorsally and ventrally 
  • The presence of a gastrinoma within this triangle can cause hypersecretion of gastric acid, leading to symptoms such as recurrent peptic ulcers and diarrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Calot's triangle: Calot's triangle is an anatomical triangle in the upper abdomen that is relevant to gallbladder surgery. It is formed by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver.

Option C - Doom's triangle: The dangerous triangle (the triangle of doom) refers to a triangular area bound by the vas deferens, the testicular vessels and the peritoneal fold.

Option D - Cholecystohepatic triangle: It is another name for the calot’s triangle and it is an incorrect option as also described above.

questions.text: ​​​​​​​In the OPD, a 35-year-old male presented with concerns of passing dark-colored stools. Following an endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. Which anatomical structure serves as a distinguishing point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ligament of Treitz:

  • The Ligament of Treitz, also known as the suspensory muscle of the duodenum, is a fibrous band located at the junction between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and the jejunum (the second part of the small intestine).
